We want to benefit the states over the long term so that they can meet their commitments in relation to health, education and—
Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! I remind senators on my left that persistent interjecting is out of order.

—We want to support the states in providing for their obligations in health, education, housing and so forth, and provide a funding pool to enable that to occur in the future rather than run the risk of that being undermined over time. We want to give particular benefits to the export industry—
—You don't. This is rubbish.

—in order that we can lock into what I hope will be a future growth picture within the region, Senator Cook, and provide an answer to not only the current account problems but also Australian jobs for the future. So I would have thought the benefits in this tax reform would have been obvious, even to the Labor Party. It has been obvious to the Labor Party at times in their past but, for reasons of political opportunism, of course, they do not wish to see it at the moment.

answer.para: There is no doubt that if we do not go down this path we will be less competitive than the majority of economies in the world that have already adopted this area of tax reform. It is true that we want to do it in a way that is as simple as possible and in which the compliance costs are as low as possible. That is true.

talk.start.para: —Order!

—So, on balance, we will not move away from an opportunity that enables us to fundamentally reform Australia's outdated, outmoded taxation system in a way which will give real benefits to all Australians.
—Order! I remind opposition senators that persistent interjecting is disorderly. Persistent and wilful interjection and disregard for the authority of the chair can have certain consequences.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Now that the minister has conceded that his view of 18 February is in the past tense—that he has apparently agreed that he has changed his view from February of this year—what now is the government's estimate of the compliance costs to small business of exempting food from the GST?

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator HILL
talker.role: Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: —I repeat what I said: we want compliance costs to be as low as possible; therefore, we want the system to be as simple as possible. That remains our desired outcome in any negotiations that are taking place at the moment because we want the maximum benefits to flow to the Australian economy and therefore to all Australians, and particularly to those who are unemployed. That is what Labor cannot seem to understand. By ensuring continued economic growth, we have the best opportunity to provide jobs for Australians who are out of work. That is why we are committed to taxation reform, and that is why we are committed to reform that can be achieved at the lowest possible cost.
—My question is to the Assistant Treasurer, Senator Kemp. What is the significance of Standard and Poors' upgrading of Australia's credit rating from AA to AA plus?

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator KEMP
talker.role: Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: —Thank you, Senator Calvert, for that most important question. Senator Calvert reminds us of a very important announcement that was made last week.
—Kempy, lift your game.
—Senator Faulkner, you should not be shouting in that fashion.

—It has taken this country 10 years to recover part of the way from Labor's economic mismanagement which cost this country not just one but two credit rating downgrades. The ratings agency Standard and Poors first downgraded our foreign currency debt rating to AA plus in August 1986 under the Hawke Labor government. Confirming the then major external imbalances in the Australian economy, Australia was further downgraded to a AA credit rating in October 1989.

answer.para: However, just last week Standard and Poors announced that Australia had been upgraded back to a AA plus credit rating, the second highest international credit rating. This is a very important independent objective endorsement of the quality of Australia's fiscal management and performance prospects. It was a decision made for four main reasons: the rapidly decreasing net foreign debt of the public sector, falling from 87 per cent of annual exports in 1994 to 35 per cent now; the wide consensus of continued fiscal restraint; Australia's prudent monetary policy and low inflation; and favourably, of course, the very good performance of the Australian economy.

History will note as fact that the last Labor government, at the stage when of course the current Leader of the Opposition was finance minister, presided over a downgrading of Australia's credit rating. Australia's credit rating upgrade is a recognition that the economic course the Australian government is currently following is right for the times. The policies of the Howard government are bringing their own rewards: low interest rates, the lowest in memory; low inflation, running at substantially lower levels than in the OECD; rising real wages; more jobs—the unemployment rate now, of course, is around a nine-year low; and a strong and growing economy. The Australian economy is growing faster than the economies in Europe and even faster than the high-performing US economy.

The coalition delivered a surplus budget this year, last year and the year before that, and has repaid debt shamelessly accumulated by the last government who ran Australia into the red by close to $80 billion. Credit ratings are an indication of the economic performance of this government, and it is fitting to recall that when Labor was in government it presided over two downgrades. The coalition has the runs on the board. We have a strong record and we are facing an opposition which is determined to block reform and change at every opportunity.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business, Senator Alston. Does the minister recall informing the Senate on 17 February 1999:

question.para: . . . trying to exempt food would be an absolute nightmare, a legal maze, a quagmire into which small business would sink without compensation for it.
Given the minister's concerns regarding the cost to small businesses of exempting food from the GST, what compensation would be necessary if food were to be exempted?

talk.start.para: —No brief?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —You do not need a brief on this one, Senator Carr. The fact is that Senator Conroy's belated interest in the subject matter is welcome but, unfortunately, Labor dealt themselves out of a place at the table many, many months ago. If you had wanted to be serious about tax reform you had every opportunity. You have been urged by some of your retired colleagues to actually get fair dinkum about the issue. Mr Della Bosca wears a halo these days, doesn't he, amongst some of you? There he is; he is out there telling you that you made monumental mistakes in not talking to the government about Telstra.

answer.para: Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Senator, would you direct your remarks to the chair. Senators on my left should cease shouting.

—Madam President, we should not have jokes interjected like that; we could somehow be asked to take them seriously. The fact is, of course, that the government will be seriously addressing all the issues that Labor manifestly failed to address, that they had the opportunity to address. The discussions that we are having with the Australian Democrats are very constructive, unlike the obstructive approach that you have adopted from day one. I can understand why it is, because Mr Beazley is a burned out case. He is not interested in reform of any shape or sort. And, of course, the last thing he would want is to have to sit down and go through the long hard slog of trying to work out what might be doable and what is not.

answer.para: Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Nice of you to turn up before half-time, Senator Ray.

—Order! There are far too many interjections. I have already spoken to Labor senators. Your behaviour is not in accordance with the standing orders. Some are persistently and I believe wilfully breaching the orders.

—What ought to be recognised is that the Australian Democrats went through the last election campaign acknowledging that the GST had particular virtues in terms of reforming the Australian taxation system. They know that it will remove all of those monumentally complicated arrangements that currently exist because of the wholesale sales tax arrangements. You are not interested in any of those. You have not learned from the experience of the last election, where the punters caught you short. You were stark naked, going into the election with no policies. It is a criminal offence in electoral terms, and you just cannot get away with it.
—Order! Senator Alston, you must address your remarks to the chair and not directly across the chamber.

—Madam President, the GST will introduce a much simpler approach than the current wholesale sales tax system, particularly for small businesses. The new pay-as-you-go system will replace five different and complex systems. So small business will be a major winner. And, of course, all of those who had the chance at the last election and voted yes know full well that there is only one game in town, and you are not part of it.

—My question is to the Minister for the Environment and Heritage. The government has previously indicated its willingness to seriously consider using, if necessary, the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species, CITES, to protect the Patagonian toothfish and the southern bluefin tuna.

question.para: Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order!

—I am sorry that species extinction is not of concern to the ALP, but it is certainly of concern to the Democrats. Given the lack of progress through other channels in protecting these marine species, will the government now act to prevent the extinction of these species by proceeding with nominating them under CITES?

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator HILL
talker.role: Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: —I thank the honourable senator for the serious question, which is more than I get from the ALP.

answer.para: Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! Senator Faulkner, you and your colleagues should not be shouting across the chamber. There is a level of sledging going on during this question time which is totally out of order and unacceptable. You are denying the authority of the chair by shouting in that fashion.

—Madam President, on a point of order: I think you would have noted during the last question asked by Senator Bartlett that most of the noise in the chamber was opposition senators laughing at the Democrats and the government. It was not sledging.
—That is not correct, and there is no point of order.

—In response to the question, yes, we have said that we would consider a CITES listing for the two species mentioned by the honourable senator—the Patagonian toothfish and the southern bluefin tuna. That meeting of CITES is next year. But we have also said that we do not think that it is the best option for conservation of either species. In relation to the Patagonian toothfish, the honourable senator would be aware of the actions that we took at the CCAMLR meeting late last year in Hobart: basically to increase conservation measures with observers on vessels, vessel monitoring devices so that they can be followed by satellites and the like, and increasing surveillance as well.
—And nothing happened. What have you done about it?
—The honourable senator says `Nothing happened.' I might remind him that, using surveillance this year, no vessel was found in Australian waters in breach of our jurisdiction.

answer.para: In addition, we said that it would be wise to move towards a stock certification scheme and trading restrictions, and we said that we would take that to a special meeting—which we caused to be held—of CCAMLR in Brussels last month. That meeting was held and, in relation to putting in place such a scheme which would be a disincentive for the taking of illegal stock because it would be much more difficult to trade in that stock, I think it is fair to say we achieved about three-quarters of our objectives. We are currently considering what further action we should take before this year's meeting of CCAMLR because there is no doubt that an effective CCAMLR regime not only respected by all CCAMLR parties but also supported by an effective certification and trade scheme is the best way to conserve the Patagonian toothfish.

In relation to the southern bluefin tuna, the best option is of course to operate within the commission and to have it work effectively. I take the opportunity of commending Senator Parer for the work that he did in regard to the increased experimental take of the Japanese to which we have been, and continue to be, opposed. There are some slow but positive steps being taken. In particular, there are good vibes with additional countries coming within the commission which will make a significant difference. But the negotiation which is taking place at the moment continues to be difficult. If the commission can be made to work effectively, there is no doubt in my mind that that is a more effective way of conserving the stock than through CITES because, as the honourable senator will know, states can simply exempt themselves from the application of CITES and thus it becomes ineffective as far as they are concerned.

So what I can say to the honourable senator is: yes, we are looking at all options that will enable us to better conserve both these species which are under considerable pressure at the moment. CITES remains one option that is on the table but there are other options that may in fact be better, so we are not avoiding taking full opportunity of those options as well.
Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! Labor senators will cease shouting.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for his answer. I realise that bodies such as CCAMLR and CCSBT are considering this issue, but obviously they have not been effective enough in preventing ongoing damage and threat to the species despite the positive but, as you say yourself, slow progress. If the government waits until the next CCAMLR meeting in November, how much more time will you have to commit to a CITES nomination before the CITES meeting deadline? Surely if you make the decision now to announce you will seek to get CITES listing it would put more pressure on these other bodies to ensure they come to effective agreements that will make not only slow and positive progress but also concrete and firm progress in preventing the demise of these species.

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator HILL
talker.role: Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: —That is a judgment we have to make but, on the other hand, we have the concern that if we move towards CITES now it may well be interpreted as a signal that we are placing less reliance upon the other two methods, and in particular the need to strengthen and improve those methods. That is why we have been cautious about taking that step. But, as I said, the CITES possibility is on the table and we will continue to work down a path to achieve the best possible conservation outcomes.
—My question is to Senator Kemp, the Assistant Treasurer. Does Senator Kemp recall informing the Senate on 15 February 1999:

question.para: . . . there would be major problems for the tax package, as you are aware, if food were extracted from that tax package and made GST free. I think the experience in other countries around the world has shown that it would lead to major issues of compliance and major costs of compliance.

To what extent do compliance costs rise as a consequence of exempting food from the GST, and does the minister stand by his statement that there would be major problems if food were exempted from the GST?

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator KEMP
talker.role: Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Sherry for that question. I recall during the debate on the GST bills Senator Sherry being asked a question about the Labor Party policy, and he urged us all to wait at least 1½ years until the federal conference of the Labor Party. Senator Sherry has also indicated he is a very strong supporter of the wholesale sales tax. It was quite interesting that Mr Beazley was asked a question on the wholesale sales tax on the weekend, and this is what Mr Beazley was asked:

answer.para: Given the experience of the Keating Government in 1993, can you give a guarantee that if you become Prime Minister, Wholesale Sales taxes will not go up?
We waited and we waited, and he finally said this:
I certainly think we could guarantee that unquestionably for the life of one Parliament.

This is your tax—your wholesale sales tax. It has become very clear that there is no lock-in there; Mr Beazley said maybe for the term of one parliament. As Senator Hill put it, we are in the process of trying to reform a broken-down tax system. We are in the process of trying to have a tax system which will fit Australia for the 21st century. We are the party of tax reform and the Labor Party have set themselves against tax reform. It is very clear—and the government can read the numbers in this chamber—that it makes sense for us to have negotiations with the other parties in this chamber to see whether we can get a major tax reform package through this chamber. That is precisely what we are trying to do. That is what the Australian public would expect us to do, and Senator Sherry—as with Senator Faulkner and all his other colleagues—will have to await the outcome of the negotiations that we are having with the Australian Democrats.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Senator Kemp, you say you are in the process of reforming a broken tax system, and apparently you are going to adopt a solution that, according to Mr Costello, is a `nightmare on Main Street'. But are you aware of the reported comments of Gerry Taylor, from the Institute of Chartered Accountants, regarding GST compliance costs for small business? He warned:

question.para: If food is taken out of the GST, then it will be much more complex and the compliance will be more costly.

Isn't the realisation of growing compliance costs one of the reasons why more and more small business owners are doubtful of the benefits of the GST, and fewer business owners actually support the tax package according to the latest Yellow Pages Small Business Index?

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator KEMP
talker.role: Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: —One thing is absolutely clear: small business does not support the Labor Party. Small business does not support the political arm of the trade union movement and never will. We are about delivering major tax reform. We are delivering major tax reform so that this can benefit the economy, small business, medium sized business and big business. That is what we are about, and that is the reason why we are having negotiations with the Democrats on this important issue—to see whether we can move the tax reform process forward.

—My question is to the Minister for the Environment and Heritage. In relation to his negotiations with Senator Allison from the Democrats on the environmental impact of the proposed GST package, will the $1 billion offered at the outset in diesel fuel rebates by the Democrats not be effectively a $40 per tonne subsidy to woodchip trucks taking woodchips from Australia's wild forests and exporting them to Japan? Secondly, does it not involve a $600 million or $700 million subsidy to the mining industry, including the coal industry—a prodigious producer of greenhouse gases—and even the uranium industry, with a modest component in future going to the Jabiluka uranium mine? Finally, I ask: in relation to the Patagonian toothfish and the southern bluefin tuna, will not the Democrats' proposed $1 billion subsidy involve subsidising the Australian fishing fleet fishing for those very species? (Time expired)

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator HILL
talker.role: Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: —I am pleased that the Patagonian toothfish is getting a good public airing today. It might raise community interest in the subject matter. What Senator Brown has never been prepared to accept is that, through the tax reform package, we actually seek to achieve win-win outcomes—good economic outcomes in terms of growth and job opportunities but also in an environmentally responsible way.

answer.para: In relation to diesel fuel: yes, we do want to reduce transport costs in this country, particularly in rural and regional Australia. Because of the size of Australia, we are at a competitive disadvantage compared with many of those with whom we deal. There is no secret about that. Rural and regional Australia pays high transport costs, a very high percentage of their business inputs, and we as a government wish them to be more competitive, for obvious reasons. We want them to thrive, we want them to expand and we want them to provide employment. That is why we were looking at ways in which we could reduce the costs of transport in this country.

As Senator Brown knows, although he might not want to acknowledge it, much of the transport in rural and regional Australia is diesel powered and, in many instances, there is not another practical alternative to that. That is why we have introduced this element of the reform package. It is part of the answer that I gave earlier today: that we want a more competitive economy that can enable us to build upon the achievements of the last three years and provide more jobs for Australians.

There is also an opportunity in this discussion to achieve some more environmental benefits. I am surprised that Senator Brown has so little interest in the opportunities for environmental gain that he would not bother to come and talk to us about them. He has a vote in this place as well, but how often has he said, `As a voter in this place, I want to achieve an environmental gain'? Never! All he wants to do is to stand on the other side and complain about the behaviour of others. There is an opportunity for Senator Brown in this place to further environmental opportuni ties, but he does not seem to understand how he might use it.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I rise on a point of order. I specifically asked the minister, in particular at the end, about the effect the Democrats' package of subsidising the fishing industry will have on the Patagonian toothfish and the southern bluefin tuna. I ask that you bring him back to the questions I asked in the time left for him to answer them.

—Senator, your question took more than the full minute, and there were a number of issues that you raised within it. Senator Hill is able to deal with those matters as he sees fit. I cannot direct him how to answer the question or to which bits of the question he may give greater emphasis to.

—All rural industry that has high transport costs will benefit from our tax package. Yes, rural industry in Tasmania as well, Senator Brown, will be benefited by our tax package. It will mean economic growth in Tasmania and more jobs in Tasmania. I would have thought that Senator Brown would be interested in that. If that is in the timber industry, so be it. Fuel costs in the timber industry are relatively high compared with other industries. If we can make our timber industry more competitive, I would have thought that Senator Brown—if he were interested in jobs—would applaud it. There are ways in which we can achieve environmental benefits as well. If Senator Brown is interested in seriously achieving those goals, our door is always open. I have no doubt that, through sensible discussion, he might be able to achieve something worth while as well.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I come back to the point of the Democrats' question in defence of the Patagonian toothfish and the southern bluefin tuna. I asked the minister specifically: is the Democrats' diesel fuel rebate going to apply to the fishing boats that are going to fish those very species, on their way to extinction, out of the water?

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator HILL
talker.role: Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: —This is Senator Brown's moment of theatre. We are committed to sound environmental outcomes, conservation of endangered or vulnerable species being a very important part of that. If he had listened to the answer on southern bluefin tuna and Patagonian toothfish, he would have heard exactly what this government is doing—which I have to say is more than any previous government has ever done—on the issue of marine conservation. There are a lot of ways in which he could help this government on matters of marine conservation, if he were serious about the issue, rather than wanting a moment of theatre in this place.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Senate Inquiry

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Assistant Treasurer, Senator Kemp. Is the minister aware that Senator Lees has accused the government of failing to `participate fully and properly in the Senate GST committee process' and `a lot of the material that has been put before us in the talks with the government should have been put before the Senate committees'? Why did the government attempt to deceive the Senate and the Australian people by withholding essential material from the Senate inquiry?

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator KEMP
talker.role: Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: —Of course I do not accept the premise of the question. The government has been extremely straightforward in the information it has put before the public. We sought a mandate from the Australian people for tax reform. Our tax reform plans were exposed to the public before the last election. They were widely debated in the course of the last election, and they are well known. We are quite aware a very extensive committee inquiry was established by the Senate, and the government has provided information to those committees. Certainly, if there is other information required in the course of negotiations that other parties may well be having, it can also be considered by the government.

answer.para: We believe that, unlike the Labor Party, we have been extremely straightforward in the presentation of material to the public. The Labor Party, of course, in the notorious 1993 election went to the people promising tax cuts, but they never mentioned to the people they were going to raise the wholesale sales taxes across the board, they never mentioned to the Australian people they were going to raise excise duties and they never mentioned to the people that they were going to abolish the l-a-w tax cuts. I think I can say with great sincerity that the government has been very straightforward in the information that it has put before the Australian public.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. My question was about the Senate committee. I remind the minister that Senator Lees said `a lot of material that has been put before us should have been put before the Senate committees'. Who is right—Senator Lees or you? The second question is: will the government undertake to make available to the Senate as a whole the material which it is now making available to Senator Lees and which Senator Lees has said should have been made available to the Senate GST inquiry?

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator KEMP
talker.role: Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: —Senator Lees is quite entitled to her views. It does not mean that the government has to agree with everything that Senator Lees or anyone else says in this place. We are very hopeful that, with a constructive outcome from the negotiations, the debate on the bills will proceed, and I am sure that any questions that people have will be fully and appropriately answered, as they always are.

—My question without notice is directed to Senator Minchin, the Minister for Industry, Science and Resources. Biotechnology has been described as the new frontier for science, opening up huge opportunities in medical research, industry and agriculture. I ask the minister: what is the government doing to support Australian development in this growing sector?

talker.name: Minchin, Sen Nick
Senator MINCHIN
talker.role: Industry, Science and Resources

talk.start.para: —Senator Parer is quite right: biotechnology is a very significant growth field for science. I think it offers very significant opportunities for Australian science and industry, particularly in relation to job creation and future export income. We are keen as a government to ensure that Australia captures the full benefits of this technology. We were pleased to announce as part of this year's budget an investment by the government of $17½ million towards this industry, particularly to develop a biotechnology strategy for Australia.

answer.para: I think it is interesting to note that support at both the Commonwealth and state levels for this industry already stands at $200 million to $250 million per annum through the CSIRO, CRCs, R&D assistance and state government support. Of course, our doubling of the nation's medical research budget over the next six years should also contribute significantly to our capacity in biotechnology. In the budget, we announced the establishment of Biotechnology Australia, which will be responsible for working with all the stakeholders in this industry to develop that national strategy and manage the government's biotechnology approach. We have also set up a biotechnology ministerial council to develop and monitor that strategy.

Biotechnology presents big opportunities for advances in medical science, in particular, and also for improving the quantity and quality of Australian agriculture—already at the leading edge in terms of world production. But clearly there are, as we have seen in other nations, people with some concern about the development of this industry and this technology. So in the budget we announced a commitment of $7½ million towards the establishment of a statutory office of gene regulation, in order to ensure the community has confidence in the independent regulation of biotechnology products. We also announced a commitment to a very significant public information campaign to ensure that the public fully understands the opportunities involved for Australia in this industry. Through those initiatives we can ensure that Australia can take advantage of this industry in a sensible way.

Of course, this is not our only initiative in this area of science and research. The biotechnology initiative very much complements other initiatives of the Howard government and our support for research. The total commitment by Australia to research and development now stands at around $4 billion per annum, which as a proportion of GDP puts us in the top five countries in the OECD. In fact, the budget saw an increase in our funding for science agencies. There is an extra $82 million for the CSIRO over the next three years, restoring the funding that was stripped off the CSIRO by our predecessors. We are committed to providing $664 million in this budget towards supporting business R&D—an increase of seven per cent over the previous year. We are trying to do as much as we can to support commercialisation through improvements to the pool development fund.

The biggest impediment to the development of biotechnology is clearly the capital gains tax system that we inherited from the Labor Party. The most important thing that we can do to ensure biotechnology does produce the goods for Australia is to reform the hopeless capital gains tax system we inherited from Labor. I hope that will come about as part of the review of business taxation, and we welcome Labor's support for reform of capital gains tax. The government's initiatives will help ensure that Australia is at the leading edge of the development of biotechnology, which could well be one of Australia's most successful and important industries in the 21st century.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to Senator Kemp, the Assistant Treasurer. Does the minister still believe, as he stated in his media release of 20 April 1999, that exempting food from the GST in the manner proposed by the Australian Democrats will result in a situation in which tinned caviar is GST free but fish fingers are taxed, and that tinned spaghetti will not be taxed but that the same spaghetti served ready to eat in a plastic takeaway container will? Does the minister still contend that there would be massive definitional problems in differentiating between fresh and processed food for the purposes of GST treatment? Has the minister's attention been drawn to any evidence that would alter his strongly held views on this subject? If so, could the minister enlighten the Senate as to what that evidence now is?

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator KEMP
talker.role: Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Forshaw for that question. The truth of the matter is that this government is after major tax reform: tax reform for the benefit of the Australian community, tax reform which will deliver major tax cuts and tax reform which will continue the fiscal responsibility which has so marked this government.

answer.para: It is no secret at all that negotiations are being carried out by the government to see whether we can constructively advance the tax reform agenda. If Senator Forshaw wanted to know the nature of those discussions and wanted to be fully appraised of the details which are occurring in the course of the discussions, the Labor Party should have adopted a positive attitude to tax reform, but it did not. The Labor Party counted itself out of the game from day one. The Labor Party is completely irrelevant to the tax reform process. We make no apology whatsoever for seeking to advance the cause of tax reform.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I raise a point of order. The minister's answer is totally irrelevant to the question. The question related to his specific comments in a press release of 20 April where he said that exempting food would cause significant definitional problems. I have asked him whether he still holds those views or whether he has altered them and, if he has, on the basis of what evidence. So far he has spent pretty close to three minutes talking about everything except the question. Madam President, would you mind asking him to at least have a go at answering the question?
—The minister has been dealing with the subject that was raised in your preamble and question.
—The subject that was raised—

—I raise a point of order, Madam President. At no stage in my question did I ever raise the issue of so-called tax reform, which is what the minister claims he is talking about. I take it from your ruling that this is, in fact, tax reform. I never mentioned the words in my question, but that is what the minister claims he is answering. I asked a question specifically about his views in relation to a GST on food. So far he has not said one word on that issue.
—There was a preamble and a question and the minister is able to comment on the preamble. I am sure he is aware of the question.

—Of course the question involved tax reform. If Senator Forshaw wants to be part of the overall debate on tax reform he is in the wrong party. The Labor Party has no intention of pursuing any tax reform agenda. Senator, if you want to know what is going on around the table, you are in the wrong party.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, Senator Ian Macdonald. I ask the minister: what progress has there been in the government's announced intention to re-establish the G airspace trial between Canberra and Ballina? What is the timetable for re-establishing the trial? What measures will the government be taking to ensure the near misses and safety problems that occurred during the last trial are not repeated?

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator IAN MACDONALD
talker.role: Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Woodley for that question.
—Of course, of course! Of course you do.
—Order! I warn opposition senators that the behaviour that has been going on this afternoon is disorderly and will not be tolerated.
—Senator Woodley has an ongoing interest in aviation matters. In fact, he has asked—

answer.para: Senator Carr interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Senator Carr, I remind you of the standing orders.

—He has asked a number of questions about aviation matters. I can recall answering about three or four in this chamber. I observe, in passing, that the Labor Party have not asked one since I have been in this position.

—I rise on a point of order. Madam President, it is quite clearly disorderly for Senator Macdonald to talk about Labor Party questions when answering a question from Senator Woodley. He ought to continue with his shameless crawling to the Australian Democrats.
—There is no point of order.
—I was simply observing, in response to interjections from the Labor Party, that you never get a serious question from them about policy issues.

—Madam President, I rise on a point of order. Quite clearly Senator Macdonald is out of order in answering the question in this way. I ask you to rule him out of order. He has been given a dorothy dix by Senator Woodley. Why doesn't he get on and answer it?
—There is no point of order.
—Madam President, I keep responding to the interjections by the Labor Party. I should not do so.
—I think you should perhaps ignore them, Senator, and deal with Senator Woodley's question.

—I appreciate that, Madam President. Last year, as Senator Woodley would know, because he follows this—the Labor Party have no interest in it whatsoever—CASA conducted a trial of class G airspace in the Canberra-Ballina corridor. The trial was concluded on 13 December by Mr Mick Toller, the Director of the Civil Aviation Safety Authority. The key feature of the proposed changes to class G airspace is that they introduce radar based information in the airspace for the first time, subject to availability. I am aware of recent press quotes—and that is what Senator Woodley was perhaps referring to—from Mr Toller stating that changes to G-class airspace will go ahead and that Airservices Australia is drafting a sensible timetable for introduction of the new changes.

answer.para: On 11 January this year, the Civil Aviation Safety Authority published a summary of responses to industry comments relating to the trial of changes to G-class airspace. The summary contained a new partial proposal for changes to class G airspace in terminal areas, taking into account the responses collected. In releasing the new partial proposal, CASA has once again sought industry comment and that comment period closed on 28 February this year. CASA is now reviewing the comments received. No changes are expected to the class G airspace over the next nine months pending the outcome of the BASI investigation into last year's trial and the full implementation of the TAAATS program. The government is committed to regulatory reform in aviation and will continue to seek significant progress towards best practice. I emphasise, as always, that for the government, and for Senator Woodley obviously, safety is paramount in these reforms.

I conclude by again thanking Senator Woodley for the question. He does have an interest in this topic. I find it a little sad that the opposition do not take an interest in these matters. They never seem to be interested in any sensible policy position and can only be negative about this, as they are about all things.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for his answer. Arising out of that answer, particularly the reference to media reports, I ask the minister about a comment by the Acting Chairman of the Civil Aviation Safety Authority, Mr Paul Scully-Power, who was reported in the Australian newspaper recently as telling staff that they must `get on with the job of restoring public confidence in the authority'. I ask the minister: what will the government be doing to repair the damage done to CASA and to public confidence in Australia's air safety regulation during the regime of the former chairman?

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator IAN MACDONALD
talker.role: Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: —The Civil Aviation Safety Authority has released draft proposals to restructure CASA. As Senator Woodley and government senators would know, there has been some concern about the efficiency of CASA and for that reason CASA undertook this consideration of restructure. The proposed new structure outlines the arrangements to support CASA's three core areas of safety compliance, safety standards and safety promotion. CASA is responding to concerns that have been raised and is working in a very constructive way, consulting inter ested aviation bodies, to make sure it is very effective in doing what it is there to do, and that is to regulate safety for Australian airlines.
—Madam President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —On Thursday, 29 April Senator Brown asked me, as the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, a question, part of which I took on notice. I have now received from the Minister for Defence an answer to the remainder of the senator's question, which I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard .

speech.para: Leave granted.
On Thursday, 29 April 1999 (Hansard page 3884) Senator Brown asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Defence, the following question without notice

I refer to the Australian Defence Force's s welcome two-year contract with Incat Tasmania worth $38 Million for the supply of a high-speed catamaran to the armed forces. Can the minister tell the senate what the nature of that contact is—sale, lease or otherwise—and whether Tasmanian duties, such as stamp duties, will be paid on that sale or, if not, whether some arrangement will be made to compensate Tasmania for taxes forgone in this very welcome sale by Incat?
The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question which I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard .

(1) At this time, there are two contractual relationships currently being negotiated. The main agreement is the charter agreement which is anticipated will be signed next week and will be supplemented by a contract for maintenance during the period of the charter which will be finalised in the near future.
Charter Agreement

The charter agreement is known as a "Bareboat" charter which is a type of demise charter under which possession and control of the vessel is passed to the Commonwealth without master and crew. Under the charter a Naval master and crew will operate the vessel. The contractor may provide some crew for a limited period to provide advice however these would be under Naval control.

The charter agreement is based on the "Baltic and International Maritime Conference Standard Bareboat Charter" codenamed BARECON 89 adapted as appropriate. The agreement includes some minor vessel modifications to be carried out by the contractor and the training of a Naval crew. The charter agreement is for an initial period of two (2) years plus three (3) options to extend the charter period as required by the Commonwealth. The agreement may also contain options to purchase the vessel or to upgrade to a larger vessel.
Maintenance Contract

Under the charter agreement it is the charterer's responsibility to maintain the vessel to agreed standards. In keeping with current trends within the Department, it is intended to outsource these maintenance responsibilities.

(2) The extent to which stamp duties apply to a transaction, whether with the Commonwealth or with a commercial entity will depend on the nature of the instrument. As stated above, the contracts currently proposed are not a sale and would only attract nominal duties (in the order of $10 to $20). The position would be the same if a commercial entity entered into an identical contract. No arrangements will therefore need to be made for taxes forgone.

(3) As stated above there are two contractual relationships, the charter agreement and the maintenance contract. However, the total estimated cost of $38.845 million also includes personnel support costs. base support costs and fuel. The summary of cost allocation over the charter period follows:
$m
Charter costs 26.486
Modifications 0.430
Personnel support 1.000
Base support 0.300
Training 0.300
Maintenance 3.375
Fuel 6.954
Total 38.845
Yours sincerely
JOCELYN NEWMAN

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of answers given by the Assistant Treasurer (Senator Kemp), to questions without notice asked today.

In Senator Kemp, we have a politically wounded minister representing the Treasurer in this chamber, someone who the government does not have any faith in and who is not involved in the current negotiations with the Australian Democrats on the government's GST package. In question time today Senator Kemp was comprehensively unable to explain why, after months of hardline rhetoric from the government on its refusal to change the government position on anything, the Prime Minister now is suddenly willing to compromise. Mr Howard knows that Treasury has told him that if the GST is not applied to almost everything it will not work as a tax. Mr Howard believes that as soon as food and other items are exempted from the GST the tax system will become truly ramshackle. He knows that Treasury abhors an exemption, but that is what we are facing. This is the same Mr Howard who for a long time has given assurances that the GST was perfect and could not be changed. Those commitments will go into the rubbish bin of history, just like Mr Howard's claims that there are no losers or there will never, ever be a GST, or even his core and non-core promises. It will be interesting to see how many backflips on cast-iron commitments or long-held positions of principle there will be in the current negotiations with the Democrats.

Mr Howard has said again and again he will not budge on the issue of the exemption of food—food will not be exempted. He says he will fix the tax system. On 12 February, on Neil Mitchell's radio program, he took the Treasury line supporting the unified application of the GST on food. In that Sunday interview on 18 April he was asked, `Will you exempt food from the GST?' He said no. In Brisbane on 14 May he said, `We are not prepared to back down on food.' On 21 April Mr Costello said:

What the Democrats want the government to do, if this were accepted, would be to hire tax inspectors to go around putting thermometers into chickens. You really want a tax system where we're employing people sticking thermometers into chickens to try and run a tax system—it's nightmare on Main Street. It is not real life . . . It won't work . . . And we ought to get on with real tax reform which is taking complexity out of the system rather than putting it in.

That is what Mr Howard and Mr Costello said. And, of course, you cannot believe them. Now we have a situation where Senator Lees and the Democrats need to take whatever deal they can out of this from their negotiations with the government. We hear a lot of lectures about what is allegedly the most democratically driven party in the country. In a feature in the Sydney Morning Herald a day or so ago I saw that the Democrat rank and file are consulted continuously. One ex-staffer called it `Democracy gone mad'. The Democrats should take this deal back to their members and see what they say. Senator Lees revealed on the Sunday program that the government has suddenly reached into its bottom drawer and found a whole lot more information than was provided to the GST committee of the Senate. The government should disclose that information for the benefit of the Senate and the public. That would be consistent with the way Senator Lees has argued so often in this chamber, that this sort of material should be made public. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I do not know who prepares these notes for Senator Faulkner, but they prove one thing and that is I never thought I would see the day when I could compare Senator Faulkner with the former leader of the Labor Party in the Senate, Senator Gareth Evans. They suffer from the same complaint.
—Verbal diarrhoea.

—No, `relevance deprivation', I think was the term that was used. Was anybody more irrelevant than Senator Faulkner in his comments today or could anything be more irrelevant than the questions from the Labor Party today, a party that has totally dealt itself out of the exercise? The Labor Party is suffering from relevance deprivation today, and none more so than its leader in this chamber, Senator Faulkner.

speech.para: We are currently having discussions with the Democrats because they also believe the current tax system is broken and that it is in need of reform. The Democrats believe that is the case and they said so while we were receiving evidence from the various organisations and bodies that gave evidence to the select committee. The Democrats, and Senator Murray as a member of that committee, believe that the current tax system is broken and is in need of reform.

The package that we took to the election included food because we believed that including food was part of the best possible package overall. But in this chamber it is only the art of the achievable, and the Labor Party know that. I remember seeing them come into this place in 1993 with the bill generally known as the Mabo bill. When the Mabo bill left the House of Representatives the Labor Party said it was a perfect bill, but then they came and made 300 amendments to their own bill in this chamber.

I make no apologies for the fact that I believe the package that we took to the election was fair and that it was the best possible. Others in this chamber disagree with that, including Senator Harradine, who made his position quite clear. The government believe that taxation reform is important and that we must press ahead and reform the taxation system as we know it today. Only the Labor Party believe there is no need for tax reform, and that is why they are totally irrelevant when it comes to this debate. They have tried to make the issue the GST and nothing else, as though the tax reform package that we put before the people and are now debating is only dealing with the GST. There are a great number of elements in that tax package, including the new pay-as-you-go system, which will replace five different complex systems of returns every quarter. It will reduce interactions with the Taxation Office and ensure that tax payments more closely reflect trading conditions for individual businesses.

The Labor Party when in government had the opportunity to do that for 13 years and not a thing did they do to reduce the complexities of taxation as it applies to small businesses. Small businesses, if this tax reform goes through, will also benefit from the significant income tax cuts announced by the government, through a further extension of the CGT rollover relief and retirement exemption and through the reform of fuel taxation. There is a whole raft of things in this new tax system and in the tax reform package which the Labor Party are trying to deny to Australians. They are things that the small business community have been asking us for years to make changes to. They asked the Labor Party when they were in government to make some of those changes and they absolutely refused to do it.

Senator Cook talked about the government not taking part fully in the Senate committee process. I do not know where Senator Cook was, but you could have fooled me that we were not taking part fully in the Senate process. Over a period of three months we spent practically every day that we were not in this place hearing submissions at the select committee, and other committees took evidence as well. Senator Cook, in suggesting that we did not take part fully, should correct himself. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I want to take up that last point. I never accused the government of not taking part in the Senate committee process. Isn't it curious that that allegation should now be made? My question to the Assistant Treasurer in this place was whether what Senator Lees said on the Sunday program yesterday was true that a lot of information is now being made available to the Democrats that should have been made available to the Senate committee. That was the question I put. I did not accuse the government of not taking part in the inquiry. I am accusing the government of—and let there be absolutely no doubt about this, based on the answer given by the minister today and the support that Senator Lees has given to her statement on the Sunday program—not telling the truth to the Senate committee of inquiry.

speech.para: That raises a fundamental question about democracy in this country and the right of Australians to know what their government is up to. The executive wing of this government withheld information. That is what Senator Lees said, and you can run but you cannot hide from that charge. We will press that charge to get every last ounce of information that is available so that Australians do know. It was the Liberal Party that ambushed Australians with a nice, glossy piece of paper before the last election telling them of the so-called upside, selling the GST.

It was only the committee of inquiry that found pensions will erode and that pensioners will lose their benefits up to about three years after the GST comes in. It was only the committee of inquiry that found 120,000 Australians more will be out of work. It was only the committee of inquiry that found out about a major complaint from the small business community that compliance costs would escalate because this is a costly tax to collect. It was only the Senate committee of inquiry that put an end to this continual cant which we heard from the Leader of the Government in the Senate today about the elements of improvement for exports. Don't you know the exchange rate rises and the efficiencies are cancelled out? The big lie you have been telling this country is `jobs through exports'. You forget about the floating exchange rate and you do not understand or you choose to ignore how the economy works.

Since last Friday week in this chamber a number of quite important matters have arisen in Australia. The AC Nielsen poll conducted by the Age found that 58 per cent of Australians are opposed to the GST—up from 54 per cent. To the question, `Did Senator Harradine do the right thing?' the Sun-Herald poll found that 70 per cent of Australians said that he did. On the poll of which party would have won an election last week, 54 per cent of the electorate on a two-party preferred outcome would have voted for the Australian Labor Party. They are the poll findings; they are the changes that have occurred in the space of one week. If the government believes it has a mandate, why then is it refusing to go back to the electorate? You ambushed the electorate with a bunch of lies before the last election campaign. They have been revealed and now you refuse to go back. Why do you refuse to go back? Because you know that they now see through you and you will get done.

I have a letter here today—and I am sure a number of us have received it—from a company called Roxburgh Securities which thanks me for opposing the GST and gives 13 examples of what is wrong with it. The first example is that it is `regressive, complicated and inefficient'. The second is, `At an election voters will punish those parties who support it.' The third of the points is that Howard and Costello cannot be trusted. This is what John Howard said on 2 May 1995:

There's no way a GST will ever be part of our policy. Never, ever. It's dead, it was killed by the voters in the last election. The GST or anything resembling it is no longer Coalition policy. Nor will it be policy at any time in the future.

Let me conclude my remarks by again quoting from the letter. These points go on: the GST will worsen unemployment, self-funded retirees will be worse off, housing will be hit, all property will be impacted—13 points of opposition from business. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —What utter humbug and hypocrisy we are hearing yet again from the Labor Party with regard to the government's tax reform package. They are now condemning the government for giving consideration to some changes to its proposed package. They are actually condemning the government for consulting with the Democrats about the final nature of this package in an effort to pass it through the Senate. We know that consultation is something that the Labor Party know absolutely nothing about. During their 13 years in government there is example after example of their failure to consult with the community about the sorts of changes which they made during that period.

speech.para: The Labor Party's hypocrisy is demonstrated by the fact that they have the capacity to pass this tax package in its original form. They can vote with the government and pass this package as proposed by the government. But, of course, they refuse to do that because their only interest is in being spoilers. They are not interested in improving the Australian economy and tax structure; they are simply interested in being spoilers—opposition for the sake of opposition. That is what the Labor Party is about. They are not at all interested in policy. Indeed, they are a policy free zone, as we know only too well.

The Labor Party want a continuation of the ramshackle tax system that we have in operation now—the ramshackle tax system that they had during their 13 years in government and did absolutely nothing about. They want a continuation of the wholesale sales tax structure—an inefficient and outdated structure that was put in place in the 1930s. It was a tax structure for the 1930s economy and for 1930s consumption patterns. The wholesale sales tax is totally irrelevant to an Australia moving into the 21st century with growth in the importance of services both in the economy and in consumption patterns. Labor on tax are caught in a time warp. They are caught in the 1930s. They do not want any change to the structure that has been in place since then. However, Labor's think tank has come up with the brilliant idea to impose de facto death duties.
Senator Conroy interjecting—
Senator Ferguson interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! Senator Conroy and Senator Ferguson, if you wish to have a conversation could you please sit next to one another or go outside and not do it across the chamber at top note.

—The change that Labor's think tank wants to introduce is a de facto death duty. That has been recommended only in the last few days. It again shows how out of date they are: death duties were abolished more than two decades ago by the Fraser Liberal government as a result of growing community outrage about that unsatisfactory form of tax.

speech.para: The reason they are caught in this time warp is that they practise the politics of envy. It simply demonstrates that Labor are a party of the past. Their attitude to workplace relations shows that they are in a time warp and out of date. They want us to return to a workplace relations system that was in operation in the 19th century. They want to reverse the reforms and the changes that this government has made to workplace relations to set Australia up for the 21st century. The Labor Party on policy issues are nothing more than a dinosaur. They cannot extricate themselves from the 19th century or from the politics of envy—a type of politics which is quite irrelevant to Australia as it enters the 21st century.

Tax reform is essential and urgent for Australia. Our current tax system is out of date and urgently needs change. Our tax reform package is about getting rid of wholesale sales tax and replacing it with a goods and services tax and also getting rid of a number of indirect state taxes that hinder business activity and jobs growth. Part of the reform also involves changing the interface between tax and our welfare system. The current structure—the structure that Labor had when they were in office and which we want to reform—causes poverty traps and provides disincentives for people to take up opportunities to reduce their welfare dependence. Commonwealth-state financial relations have become a mess. The tax reform package will also reform that area and provide the states with a guaranteed source of revenue as the economy grows to fulfil their responsibilities.

I note that Senator Cook referred to a letter from Roxburgh Securities. I note that it was signed off by Mr Ken Helsby. Senator Cook was lauding this letter that he had received. I saw it myself. What Mr Helsby wants is to cut government spending in half. Does Labor support that? (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak on the motion to take note of the answers given by the Assistant Treasurer, Senator Kemp. I want to take up a number of points that have been made in the chamber today. Senator Chapman talked about consultation—and this comes from a government that kept secret its negotiations and discussions over the tax package—
—For 12 months.

—That is right, for 12 months the Australian public was kept in the dark. Then came the big glossy document that Senator Cook talked about. That document was put on the table and then the $20 million advertising campaign started. That was paid for by taxpayers—by everybody in this chamber and in the gallery—and what a trail of deceit it was. All the issues the government had tried to hide were exposed in the Senate inquiry. There was no modelling by Treasury. Why was no modelling ever done by Treasury? Because we know now that that modelling would not have supported a word that the Prime Minister and the Treasurer of this country uttered during the election campaign. There will be no jobs boost, no drop in unemployment, no export boost, no increase in national savings and no growth in GDP. That is what the Senate inquiry showed. It exposed you absolutely red-handed, Senator Ferguson.

speech.para: Another example of the hypocrisy of the government is the issue of compliance costs. Earlier today Senator Hill talked about compliance costs. Senator Ferguson has even talked about how small business is lauding this package, but Rob Bastian, the Chief Executive of the Council of Small Business Organisations of Australia, COSBOA, said:

" . . . small business operators now believe the GST would cost them. The exclusion of food introduces a major complexity in the tax system and for us the only reason we were copping a GST at the start was to try to produce simplicity," he told reporters. "If we excluded food, we sure would have to compensate the small business sector in some way."

The recent Yellow Pages Small Business attitude survey, released just a couple of days ago, found that two-thirds of small businesses were unable to nominate a specific benefit for them, or they said that there was no benefit. Two-thirds of small businesses said there was no benefit, only extra costs.

We have heard the argument that the government wanted to make it cheaper for small business. What did the inquiry show? It showed that at no point could it possibly be cheaper for any business because all the existing companies—the 70,000 currently in the WST system—would have their systems overtaken by the compliance costs of the GST, and those costs would be greater than the existing WST. That is something that New Zealand has just had to admit. For the other 1.6 million businesses to be dragged into the GST net, costs must go up. Why? Because any cost above zero is greater for them, and they are not paying any compliance costs on the WST.

Today we have seen one of the most disgraceful performances of grovelling to the Democrats by the whole frontbench of the government. It absolutely gave meaning to this quote from the Courier-Mail, which Senator Bartlett may have seen on the weekend. The article was by Graham Lloyd and the headline said `Doing a deal with the Democrats'. It said:
After treating Democrats leader Meg Lees like the ugly duckling at the school ball, the Liberals are now treating her like the queen of the prom.
How true is that! How embarrassing a performance was it from the entire frontbench.

Where are the Democrats at in this debate right now? Let us talk about the Democrats. Let us talk about core and non-core promises. Let us talk about the hypocrisy that the Democrats have been involved in. They lambasted this government over core and non-core promises, but what have we seen in the last week from the Democrats? We have seen first-tier promises and second-tier promises. It has been great. Core and non-core promises—we will hold you to that, Senator Bartlett.

I have a couple of points to help you with your discussions in the party room. What about the members of the National Party and trusts—entity taxation? They are going to try to sink it. They are going to do everything they can behind the scenes to sink trusts being taxed as entities and corporations. That is what they are about. What have we talked about a mandate for? The Democrats love the mandate argument. Last time I counted, 38 per cent for that lot and eight per cent for you does not come to 50 per cent. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —That was a long five minutes.

—It was a long five minutes from Senator Conroy. He had so very little to say that he had to spin it out and make the few points that he wanted to make sound as though they had some substance when they were really all nonsense and hot air.

speech.para: Senator Cook made the comment that the Australian people want to have an election on tax reform. We won an election last October—and we won it handsomely—on the issue of tax reform. Senator Cook is dreaming if he thinks the Australian people would support the Australian Labor Party now on this issue. The Australian people—as did the ALP in the past—acknowledge the need for Australia to reform its taxation system. At the moment, the ALP is attacking the new tax proposals of the government but conveniently forgetting that, in the past, ALP spokesmen such as the previous Prime Minister Paul Keating had strongly spoken of the need to reform the tax system. They supported the need for a goods and services tax or some sort of indirect taxation system.

The government, under the leadership of John Howard, took that issue to the people. It won the election in October very well on the issue of tax reform. It won the election because the Australian people understood that we need to change our tax system from a direct to an indirect system. They saw that the proposal that the Howard government was putting forward would lift the burden of personal taxation on most of the Australian population and give people more reward for their efforts.

The government strongly believes that people should be rewarded for effort. We do not want to see people taxed out of their ability to provide for themselves and feeling that, no matter how hard they work, they are going to get very little back because the taxation system, which the Labor Party wants to continue and maintain, will rob them of most of their extra income.

The tax system which we proposed, with a 10 per cent goods and services tax, was supported because it was seen as ending the vagueness of Labor's wholesale sales tax system which taxed all sorts of different items at different rates. People never knew what the real cost of things was and how much extra tax there was on an item. Under our system it will be a very simple and straightforward 10 per cent on all goods and services. People will know what the tax is and they will know where they stand. That is something the Australian people, in a majority decision, saw as benefiting the Australian community.

The other reasons for people supporting our new tax proposal were that it would make Australia more competitive, it would boost the Australian economy and, in particular, it would make Australia a stronger nation in terms of export competitiveness. Another very important reason for Australian people supporting the tax proposal put forward by the Howard government was that it would provide an income stream to the states to fund state areas of responsibility like roads, hospitals and schools, which are so important to the Australian community. According to the state governments, these are the perceived needs of each state, without the interference of the federal government. We on this side of the Senate believe that the states have a very important role to play as regional governments. That was one of the strongest reasons for people supporting our tax proposals.

We have a situation where the Australian people strongly supported our proposed taxation system. Unlike the Labor Party's wholesale sales tax system introduced in 1993, when taxes were put up in such an unprincipled manner and no compensation was paid to low income earners, our proposed taxation system will adequately compensate low income earners. The government, without any doubt, has a strong mandate to reform this system. If, in view of the current composition of the Senate, we have to negotiate with the Democrats to get it through, so be it. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

talk.start.para: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

petition.para: To Honourable Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled.
The Petition of the undersigned draws attention to the potentially damaging effects of National Competition Policy on small business such as newsagents.

Your petitioners ask the Senate in Parliament to call on the federal government to review the decisions of the Australian Consumer and Competition Tribunal which threaten the viability of newsagents and introduce legislation to override these decisions and preserve the current system of distribution for magazines and newspapers through Australian newsagents.

talk.start.para: Senator Bartlett(from 16 citizens)

petition.para: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled.

The Petition of the undersigned call on the Federal Parliament to ensure that the current regulations relating to food content are retained by the Australian New Zealand Food Authority and that adequate food labelling is introduced which allows the Australian community to make a real choice when it comes to the purchase and consumption of food.
Your Petitioners ask that the Senate support legislation which will ensure that all processed food products sold in Australia be fully labelled. This labelling must include:
food derived from genetically engineered organisms

The statements read as follows—

para.inline: STATEMENT OF REASONS FOR INTRODUCTION AND PASSAGE IN THE 1999 AUTUMN SITTINGS

speech.para: FINANCIAL SECTOR REFORM (AMENDMENTS AND TRANSITIONAL PROVISIONS) BILL
FINANCIAL SECTOR (TRANSFERS OF BUSINESS) BILL
INCOME TAX RATES AMENDMENT (RSAs PROVIDED BY REGISTERED ORGANIZATIONS) BILL

The Financial Sector Reform (Amendments and Transitional Provisions) Bill will provide for the implementation of the second stage of the Government's response to the Financial System Inquiry. It amends the Banking Act 1959, the Life Insurance Act 1995 and the Corporations Law to transfer responsibility for the prudential and corporate regulation of building societies, credit unions and friendly societies to the Commonwealth from the States and Territories. The Bill will include supplementary amendments to complement the reforms included in the first stage legislation. The Financial Sector (Transfers of Business) Bill introduces provisions which facilitate the transfer of business between life companies or authorised deposit-taking institutions on either a voluntary or a compulsory basis. The Income Tax Rates (RSAs provided by Registered Organizations) Bill ensures appropriate tax treatment for RSA business of friendly societies and other registered organizations.

The Prime Minister wrote to the Premiers and Chief Ministers on 29 November 1998 to seek their support for a draft Financial Sector Regulations Transfer Agreement. The draft Agreement seeks to achieve the transfer by 1 July 1999. Industry groups are keen to progress the transfer of regulatory responsibility for the financial institutions as soon as possible so that a single prudential regulation scheme applies across the financial sector.

para.inline: Effect if bills are not dealt with in one Sitting

speech.para: Delay in the passage of the Bills will delay the introduction and passage of the necessary State and Territory legislation to give effect to the regulatory transfer.

A delay may also be to the competitive disadvantage of building societies, credit unions and friendly societies in relation to the other financial institutions, such as banks, superannuation funds and life insurance companies (which are covered under the Bills passed in the 1998 Autumn sittings to provide for the implementation of the first stage of the Government's response to the Financial System Inquiry).
State and Territory governments may raise concerns in relation to the uncertainty created in relation to their continued regulation of these institutions.
(Circulated by authority of the Treasurer)

para.inline: STATEMENT OF REASONS FOR THE SENATE

speech.para: WOOL INTERNATIONAL PRIVATISATION BILL 1999
The purpose of the Bill is to amend the Wool International Act 1993 to convert Wool International from a statutory authority to a Corporations Law company from 1 July 1999.

The former Minister for Primary Industries and Energy announced on 15 October that ownership and responsibility for management of the stockpile would be transferred to the private sector on 1 July 1999. Industry expectation that this will occur is very high.

Failure to privatise the stockpile on or before 1 July 1999 would mean WI would resume sales from the stockpile, with a consequent renewal of the divisive industry debate about the sale schedule, and further calls for government intervention in stockpile sales. A renewal of this debate will further distract the industry from the real issues of lack of demand for wool products, the need for productivity improvements and the need to meet the quality requirements of our customers.

The Bill needs to be passed as soon as possible to allow sufficient time for all activities required for the conversion of Wool International into a Corporations Law company, including the registration of the company with ASIC.
(Circulated by authority of the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry)
