I do not have the time this afternoon to read out a very distressing letter that came to me about 13 months ago from a person who is well known to me—not only a friend but our family doctor. Her daughter went to one of these schools. In fact, it was her discussions with me years ago that had me go out to this particular special school. That was a very educational experience for me. In fact, I wrote a letter to the then education minister and, to his credit, he went out to the school as well and things started to happen.

The letter from the doctor said a number of things. It said, firstly, that the person was very sad to say that her child would no longer be going to the special school. The reasons were that, from numerous visits to the school, it was obvious that the child was getting no specialised attention and was in a dangerous environment. While she was autistic and not prone to any violent behaviour, the same could not be said of many other students there and of the one teacher in that bedroom—because it did not pass as a classroom—that was responsible for that particular environment.

A cynical person might say that the South Australian government is trying to get out from underneath on this one so that it does not get sued. I think that course of action is one that parents in South Australia who are not happy with the provision of services ought to be looking at. That will make governments and bureaucrats sit up and take note.

The letter went on to say that the child would be removed forthwith and that the mother had no more faith in the system producing the outcomes. This person was medically trained—she was a doctor. Her husband concurred with the course of action. He was a surgeon. They are not people who have no knowledge of mental disability. They are not people who do not understand the processes. They are also not people who are likely to be snowed by government bureaucrats. However, if this regulation stands, the decision they made last year would be taken right out of their hands at the whim of the bureaucracy and there would be nothing those people could do about it. I am not going to vote for that.

I want to go into this case a little further. This child is very lucky that both her parents are high income earners. Apart from the cost of the private school she goes to, they spend on private tuition what I get in salary every month. I want to repeat that: they spend what I get in salary every month on the provision of private services to help this child. They do that because they have the means, the education and the skills to pick the people to provide services and to see what can be done in this particular instance for their daughter to give her the best possible educational outcomes. If this disallowance motion were to get up, the decision to spend their money could be countervailed by negative educational experiences in some of these special schools.

The next decision is an even more important one. This child now attends one of Adelaide's private schools. A modified curriculum has been agreed to by the parents and the school. That modified curriculum has meant that this particular child can have some mainstreaming experience. That is something which I—and perhaps other senators—think is important. I think a large number of people would benefit from mainstreaming. However, it has to be done with support, with resources and with protection for all the other students in that particular educational environment. It cannot just be done. People cannot be thrown in at the deep end and expected to swim—or, indeed, to sink. It seems to be working well in this particular private school. With the program that the parents have put in place and with the program that the school has put in place with financial support from two professional people who can afford these sorts of services, that program has worked and is working as best it can in the circumstances.

A copy of this letter that came to me 13 months ago was sent to the minister and to the regional director of education. A flurry of phone calls were made to tell me that progress was still being made on this special school in South Australia. From discussions with the minister a short while ago, I understand that progress is still being made. What I saw down there some years ago now—and I understand it has not changed—disturbed me very much.

Indeed, I think the South Australian government have a real hide in wanting an exemption from the Commonwealth act so that they can direct students to go into special schools, so that they can interfere in these processes and so that they can cover their own backside when everything blows up in their face—as it very well might have done in the case that I have illustrated in the Senate this afternoon.

When the disability people came around to tell me that this proposal was going to be on the table, I looked at them with absolute disbelief. I did not think that the Commonwealth would go along with this sort of stuff. I do not know about New South Wales. I do not know what the story is there. I understand about the Motor Vehicles Act and the Firearms Act, and I suspect there are probably lots of checks and balances in that—and that is reasonable and fine—but I do know about the Education Act in South Australia. I know about it, and I have had first-hand experience of the whole system.

When I finished reading this particular letter, the only description I can give is that it was a sad letter. These parents understood that, in the process of getting a decent educational environment for their daughter, physically building a decent school was only one of the issues that the government of South Australia would have to deal with.

What I am talking about now is the physical provision of buildings, with observation areas for teachers so that they can look into other classrooms and when a need arises they can actually go in there and help out. That was only going to be the start. What was also going to be needed was a decent student to teacher ratio. The selection of staff was going to be important as well. It may not come as any shock here today that decent teachers in these environments do not last very long. The reason they do not last very long is that it is inherently unsafe for them.

One of the teachers I met on that trip to the school—and I met her subsequently afterwards—was indeed a model of the profession. She worked with students as old as 19. Her daily work involved her never taking her eyes off the students in her care for one moment. She not only had to educate these kids, to protect them, she had to toilet some of these children as well—some of them well into their teens. It should not come as any shock that she was assaulted on a regular basis. She has now left that job. The stress of that environment is so great that a person can only do it for a short length of time.

Under the principles that I adopt in relation to these things, one of the questions I ask myself is: would I like this to happen to me? It is a simple principle. If I had a child who required specialised education services—I do not, and for that I am very grateful—would I like that decision to be taken out of my hands and for my child to be put in one of these horror institutions and then forgotten about? The answer is no. That is the way I am going to vote here this afternoon.

talk.start.para: —I rise to support this motion relating to the disallowance of the Disability Discrimination Amendment Regulations 1999 (No. 1). These regulations prescribe provisions under eight separate state acts and regulations for the purposes of section 47(2) of the Disability Discrimination Act 1992.

speech.para: Disability organisations and their representatives have been calling for these regulations to be disallowed, primarily because they were formulated with no appropriate consultation and therefore fail to adequately address a number of key issues. The Attorney-General has failed to initiate any meaningful discussion or negotiation with key players, despite the fact that these regulations have been on the drawing board for nearly four years. The Attorney-General's refusal to consult with disability sector interests and with the wider community with regard to the regulations reveals a serious neglect of his ministerial responsibility and commitment to accountability.

I have spoken to and received correspondence from a number of key disability organisations that are, quite understandably, outraged by the obvious lack of consultation surrounding these regulations. The Australian Psychiatric Disability Coalition and the National Council on Intellectual Disability are among the groups that have approached me with their concerns in recent weeks. Both of these organisations at first tried to consult and negotiate with the Attorney-General via his department. However, apparently negotiating with key stakeholders is not high on this government's agenda when it comes to policy formulation.
The Attorney-General has failed to meet with either the APDC or the NCID during what should have been a consultative period in the formation of the regulations. According to the APDC and the NCID:
. . . this legislation undermines the intention and spirit of the Disability Discrimination Act to provide people with disabilities protection and justice from disability discrimination.

Under principle B of the Senate Regulations and Ordinances Committee guidelines, delegated legislation should not trespass unduly on personal rights and liberties. I would add that that particular committee is very diligent in its duty to adhere to the guidelines set down. Disability organisations have built a strong case to support their belief that these regulations are in conflict with principle B. The APDC and the NCID have both stated that:

To prescribe laws which discriminate against people with disabilities, and so denying access to Commonwealth discrimination legislation, is an undue trespass on the rights and liberties of people with disabilities.
I am sure all senators would agree with that statement.

The lack of adequate consultation undertaken by the Attorney-General has led to a situation where disability organisations are forced to oppose legislation simply because they were never even considered in the policy formulation process. Instead of including them, the Attorney-General has sought to formulate his policy in complete isolation. Consequently, we have before us a set of regulations that fails to reflect the needs and requirements of the community it seeks to govern.

The Attorney-General hoped to successfully implement a range of measures that no-one from within the field had agreed with or contributed to, and that can only indicate his arrogance and ineptitude in this role. Not only were relevant organisations and groups excluded from the consultation process but also the broader community was similarly rebuffed. These regulations were drafted without any public consultation at either Commonwealth or state level.

People with disabilities have not been informed as to the purpose of or rationale for the regulations. The regulations therefore come before parliament having received no scrutiny from interest groups, individuals or the community. The appropriate consultative mechanisms have been blatantly ignored in this highly exclusionist legislative exercise on behalf of the government.

Furthermore, the regulations inappropriately pre-empt the current development of DDA standards. Section 31 of the DDA allows the Attorney-General to formulate special `disability standards' in relation to education, employment, transport, accommodation and Commonwealth laws and programs. The regulations currently being considered run counter to current processes to develop disability standards.

The exclusionist development of these regulations can be contrasted with the more consultative processes employed in the formation of DDA standards. Representation from people with disabilities and relevant community, industry and government representatives has enabled the development of a broad consensus on DDA standard arrangements. Indeed, the Ministerial Council for Education, Employment, Training and Youth Affairs' task force has already made significant developments toward establishing an education standard. The South Australian government is currently a partner on this task force for the development of the education standard.

Despite this factor, the regulations seek to prescribe sections 75(3) and 75A of the South Australian Education Act 1972. If parts of the Education Act are to be prescribed, further negotiations in developing the DDA education standard will be thoroughly undermined. It baffles me why this government would seek to replace a consultative, open process with an exclusionist, divisive one that is already encountering significant resistance from key players.

The Australian government is duty bound to defend the interests of people with disabilities in our community through its obligations under the UN human rights standard. However, I find it particularly disturbing that we are increasingly being forced to take the government to task on these basic issues affecting the rights of the vulnerable within our community.

The recent unmet needs campaign revealed a gaping abyss in the services available to people with disabilities, their carers and families. Now the disability community is being systematically and deliberately excluded from consultation on issues that will invariably impact upon their day-to-day lives. The National Council on Intellectual Disability last weekend said $294 million was needed now to address the crisis in disability services.

In every other sector of society, key players consult and negotiate with government on the areas of direct interest to them. The Business Council is asked to comment on the GST while farmers are asked to respond to the diesel fuel rebate. However, even in 1999 the disability community is still being excluded from decisions that are invariably forced upon them. I am certain that senators would want to empower people with disabilities, rather than exclude them from the processes available to all other Australians. This government has instigated a discriminatory regime with its regulations and has ignored the very people it purports to defend.

I belong to a party that believes all Australians deserve equal rights to self-determination. The exclusionist practices of this government in formulating the regulations have been discriminatory, unfair and unethical in the extreme. Therefore, I support this disallowance motion.

talk.start.para: —I also rise to speak to this disallowance motion, to reflect the sentiments put forward by my colleagues and particularly to highlight some of the cases that Senator Quirke mentioned a little while ago. I start by commending him and Senator Gibbs as well as the people who introduced this disallowance motion, Senators Allison and Margetts, for taking the initiative.

speech.para: From time to time we do get issues like this in this place—issues which directly affect the lives of individual Australians. We obviously always have issues that affect the lives of individual Australians, but in this particular case there is a direct impact through this legislation, and through the action we take this afternoon, on the lives of so many people in our community who really need assistance from rather than to be neglected by all tiers of government, particularly the Commonwealth government.

Before us today is a motion to disallow the Disability Discrimination Amendment Regulations 1999 (No. 1). These regulations, in essence, prescribe provisions under some eight separate state acts and regulations for the purposes of subsection 47(2) of the Disability Discrimination Act. The effect of this, essentially, is to allow exemption under subsection 47(2) for any act performed in direct compliance with the legislation—such as those eight acts that I just referred to. Subsection 47(2) was in fact included in the Disability Discrimination Act in order to allow the states and territories to continue to act in direct compliance with laws but with laws which would otherwise breach the principles underlying the Disability Discrimination Act.

In essence a mechanism was found—I suppose primarily in many circumstances for an interim period—in the interests of good public policy to allow for exemptions from the Disability Discrimination Act. There was also a recognition that in some circumstances—once again in the interests of good public policy—a longer lasting exemption would also be necessary. This disallowance motion is essentially looking at the operation of subsection 47(2). The purpose of the provision was to allow the Commonwealth, states and territories time in which to modify their laws, where appropriate, to comply with the Disability Discrimination Act. The other alternative is to seek prescription under 47(2). The period of three years from when the legislation was passed expired on 30 June 1995. The issue confronting us today is whether we should allow continued exemption from the Commonwealth legislation three acts of the New South Wales parliament and some five acts of the South Australian parliament.

This side of the parliament is concerned—we believe it is a concern on the part of all non-government senators—not only about the outcome we are dealing with but also the process that was embarked on, which we also find before this parliament today. This process meant that those most deeply affected by the exemption from the legislation were not consulted. They were not consulted by any tier of government, I suppose it is fair to say. We should be concerned about the aspect of the national government and what sort of responsibility the national government should be showing on these matters.

The national parliament showed responsibility when we first passed the legislation and, in doing so, set down guidelines, standards and acceptable patterns of behaviour that we believed should govern this area of how we handle disabled people in our community. So the parliament assumed a responsibility in passing that legislation. It also sent a very clear message to government that the Attorney-General would have an ongoing role to play in this area of public policy. This ongoing role essentially meant that matters would have to go to the Attorney-General, and the Attorney-General would be accountable to parliament in respect of those matters.

What we have here is a failure by the Commonwealth Attorney-General and by the national government to fulfil such a responsibility. We should not let this now lead to a situation where that failure of responsibility is also adopted by the national parliament. It comes as no surprise in a sense because we are now at the end of a three- or four-year period where there has been a consistent eradication of the standard of protection for the disabled in our community. Whether it has been through the dwindling of resources in important mechanisms such as the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission, whether it is increasing disregard of the plight of disabled people by departments such as the Attorney-General's Department, those patterns of behaviour have continued for quite some time.

It is basically a philosophy that pervades the total government. This government believes that we should go back to the days of the late 1960s when responsibilities concerning the whole social structure of resources in our society, whether it be education or health, were the primary responsibility of the states. In the 1960s and early 1970s the conservative parties believed that the national parliament did not have a continuing role to play in respect of those areas, other than some general funding arrangements which were entered into annually or over a longer period. But it was essentially only after the late 1960s and early 1970s that there was an assumption of greater responsibility by national parliaments in respect of areas such as this.

One of the real concerns I have about the current debate on the GST package is that hidden in there—far from public view but very much at the forefront of considerations of this government—is a commitment by this Prime Minister and this government to send functions back to the states. You hear the Prime Minister talking in code, saying, `We want to give the states a guaranteed base for funding so that they can meet their traditional responsibilities.' He is never asked what they are; he is never pinned down as to what they might be. But you can be sure that it will lead to a situation where more and more responsibilities will be flicked back to the states.

There is no deal that the Australian Democrats can get into now that will protect against more and more responsibilities being flicked back to the states—responsibilities such as monitoring disability services across the community in education, health care and child care. All of these services will go back to the states in the traditional Menzies-Howard way. The states will be told, `You've got your guaranteed base funding. If you need more, then you ask to put the GST rate up. If you don't do that, then you have to survive within the resources that you have, although we are throwing more responsibilities back to you.' As I say, there is absolutely no deal that the Australian Democrats can get into today that will protect against that devolution of authority. They should not go down this alley blinded by their naivety that things will be all right because at the end of the day there will be a guaranteed base of income.

Just look at the pattern of behaviour of this government and this Prime Minister: this is a prime minister that wants to wind back national responsibility; this is the government that wants to wind back national participation and involvement. Whether it is the environment, whether it is education, whether it is child care—whatever you look at—the government wants accountability and funding sources to go back to the states. This is another instance of where we are laying the foundations for abdication of responsibility by the federal parliament.

While the Democrats are having their deliberations and going through these secret meetings that they have condemned others for having in the past, just keep in mind Senator Bartlett and all of your colleagues, and just keep in mind Mr Raper of ACOSS, that you are basically laying the foundations here for a return to 1960s and 1970s policy formulation and policy delivery. That has to be of major concern to those interested in the GST debate, even though it has not come to the forefront of the discussion so far. I challenge anyone to go back through the interviews, through the speeches and through the questions without notice in the parliament and identify those code words of a prime minister longing for the pre-Whitlam days of the 1960s in his desire to drive the social agenda back to the states. As I say, if this happens the states will get more and more responsibilities of the kind we see in the disallowance motion that is before us today.

We have here an Attorney-General who basically has said, `This is not my responsibility.' We have an Attorney-General and a government who over the years have said, `This is an area of disability that we will take less and less responsibility for,' whether in respect of funding for HREOC or funding in other departments. That this must be of major concern to us is highlighted by the fact that, in this particular instance, once again the Attorney-General has abdicated his responsibility and the national government has abdicated its responsibilities also.

Notwithstanding the fact that neither the Attorney-General nor the government consulted prior to their abdicating the field in the face of this issue, the issue itself has been a live one for quite some time now. The Attorney-General and the government have refused to consult. They have refused to engage. They have refused to sit down with those in the community who have `primary carriage'—I suppose that is the best way of putting it—of this issue. They have refused to discuss with those who are involved with this particular issue what their major concerns are in an attempt to mete out some arrangement with the states that basically would accommodate some, if not all, of those concerns.

Senator Quirke I think put forward quite clearly one particular live situation of concern. But this debate this afternoon has to highlight the fact that we are talking here about a regime of state legislation. The Commonwealth should have sat down with the states and said, `Let's go back to the drawing board; with a degree of goodwill and cooperation, there are issues that can be overcome here.' But that did not happen. So there has been no consultation, no discussion since the passing of legislation by state jurisdictions; since the issue has arisen in this place, basically there has been no discussion.

The only meaningful discussion to have taken place has been in this parliament, in the Senate, as a consequence of this particular motion to strike out the regulations. That has led the opposition to a situation where we have been able to analyse—as have the minor parties, I am sure—the subject areas before us. In respect of those subject areas and that legislation, as my colleagues have indicated, there are bills with which we are concerned, there are acts with which we are concerned—and there are certain acts with which we are greatly concerned.

We have substantial concern, for instance, with the New South Wales Motor Traffic Regulations, clauses 10(1)(c) and 11; two sections of the South Australian Firearms Act 1977; and the South Australia Motor Vehicles Act 1959, sections 88 and 148. With our concern over those pieces of legislation, the government's knee-jerk response will be to say, `If you bowl over, knock off what we are trying to do here this afternoon, there will be danger to the community.'

In answer let me put this: if we do knock off what is being attempted here this afternoon, if we do disallow those regulations, there is sufficient time for the government to do now what it should have done before—and that is to go back and talk to the states and try to get them to pass legislation which would be in closer conformity with national disability discrimination legislation. There is time to do that. If the government is concerned about indirect and unintended consequences, then the mechanism of appeal is available. Let us face it: an appeal will take much longer than a meeting with ministers, two state and one federal, to resolve any outstanding issue. There is more than enough time for any amending legislation to be passed in the state jurisdictions to accommodate any problem.

Let me say further on that point that, over the years, experience has been that the operation of the Firearms Act and the two road traffic acts has not led to any problems. That has been our experience and the experience of the jurisdictions about which we are talking.

We have substantial concerns about quite a breadth of other legislation also. We are concerned about the breadth of prescription and unintended consequences of the New South Wales Mental Health Act and Regula tions. But, as I have said, we believe that those unintended consequences could very easily be resolved by negotiation—and that negotiation could be undertaken now.

We are concerned that there is inherent discrimination in the Workers Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 1986 of South Australia. It discriminates between mental disorders and other injuries and disabilities. That sort of state legislation could very easily be brought into line with the federal legislation that operates currently. But, once again, the federal government has made no attempt to do that. We would like to see this government encouraging the South Australian government to address that issue directly in the South Australian parliament by way of legislation; and I am sure that legislation would receive the support of the opposition in that state parliament.

We are concerned also about the South Australian Education Act. Our concerns here are not easy ones and I think were put on the record quite elaborately by Senator Quirke. We do have standards in respect of many of these areas. We do have standards under Commonwealth legislation. In a sense, it is quite bewildering to realise that we do not demand the application of those standards in respect of this particular area.

The disability community is concerned that the prescription of these provisions in the South Australian Education Act pre-empt the development in that state of a disability standard by removing the need for the South Australian government to negotiate over its content. Once again, it comes back to what this debate is all about. The government, by pursuing this course by regulation, is removing access. For instance, in the South Australian situation, it has removed access to the development of a disability standard, one which could more fairly treat the disabled in the South Australian community who are applying or entering the education process.

The last area I should mention is the South Australian Industrial and Employee Relations (General) Regulations. These relate to the operation in that state of sheltered workshops. In that state, people who work in sheltered workshops do so on less than award wages. These regulations seek to maintain a lower than acceptable rate of return for those people. But there has been inquiry after inquiry, report after report, from 1992, through 1995, to 1997. Inquiries have been had by committees of this parliament, a review has been conducted by the Commonwealth Disability Services program and a report was done in 1997 by the Department of Health and Family Services.

Basically, all these found that we should not be addressing the question of financial viability of sheltered workshops by providing for the payment of reduced wages to those working there; that there are other ways of handling that issue. In fact, they said it was not only anachronistic but also offensive that people working in these workshops be expected to do a day's work on the basis of under award wages.

I could go on and on about some of the consequences of the government's regulations but, in conclusion, I make two points. The first is that we oppose the regulations and support the disallowance motion, and we do so on the basis of the direct consequences on the lives of the disabled in our community. We also do so in the knowledge that it would not take all that much effort by a federal government to meet its responsibilities to ensure a negotiation process here.

My second point is the one I started off with: this is a great example of where the federal government abdicates responsibility. It is a great example of where they cut back on their resources, on their monitoring and on their accountability mechanisms, and they give that function back to the states. I have to say to Senator Bartlett and other Democrats: if a GST package gets through this House in the next few weeks, we will be seeing a lot more of that.

talk.start.para: —I wish to speak on behalf of Senator Lyn Allison who, together with Senator Margetts, put forward the motion we are now debating. The Democrats are keen that the Senate appreciate the effect these regulations would have if they continued to be in force. They are, basically, a licence to discriminate. I take this opportunity to thank Senator Margetts for her contribution. The Democrats support the contribution she has made and the contribution which I am sure she is going to make in reply at the end of this debate.

speech.para: These regulations relate to the Disability Discrimination Act, which was passed by this parliament in 1992. It is quite a significant piece of legislation. The preamble outlines the objects of the act, and it is worth going over them again. Among the objects are:
(a) to eliminate, as far as possible, discrimination against persons on the ground of disability in the areas of:
(i) work, accommodation, education, access to premises, clubs and sport; and
(ii) the provision of goods, facilities, services and land; and
(iii) existing laws; and
(iv) the administration of Commonwealth laws and programs; and
(v) to ensure, as far as practicable, that persons with disabilities have the same rights to equality before the law as the rest of the community; and
(vi) to promote recognition and acceptance within the community of the principle that persons with disabilities have the same fundamental rights as the rest of the community.

Although each of these objects is certainly important, the Australian Democrats see the last one as capturing, in many ways, the essential spirit of the Disability Discrimination Act, and it warrants repeating. It is:
(vi) to promote recognition and acceptance within the community of the principle that persons with disabilities have the same fundamental rights as the rest of the community.

It must be said, however, that if we are going to recognise and accept the principle that persons with disabilities have the same fundamental rights, then implicit in that statement is the right for them to be consulted on actions that may affect their rights.

These regulations and, more importantly, the way they were formulated give rise to another question mark over Australia's national human rights record. It is somewhat astounding that the government has not properly consulted with disability advocacy groups on the formulation of these regula tions. It is not enough to simply say, `It is a state and Commonwealth matter.' It is a matter that directly affects people with disabilities, and they should be consulted as widely as possible. It is equally surprising that the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission has not been consulted in their formulation. I put on the record, on behalf of the Democrats for future reference by the government, that the Democrats will not countenance the peeling back of the human rights of Australians. In fact, it is the Democrats' specific policy intention to broaden the scope of antidiscrimination legislation at Commonwealth and state levels, and these regulations, in the Democrats' view, run counter to that principle. The unfortunate aspect of the government's approach to these regulations is that they were so unnecessary.

I draw attention to another part of the Disability Discrimination Act, namely section 31, which allows for the creation of what the act refers to as disability standards. In many ways, these are regulations in their own right, but they are positive in nature because of their educative effect. The standards seek to establish benchmarks in a whole raft of areas, including employment, education, accommodation, public transport services and facilities, and the administration of Commonwealth laws and programs in respect of persons with a disability. Anyone who has a disability—or experience with friends or relations who live with a disability—will know exactly how difficult mobility can be on public transport systems. I take the opportunity to congratulate state and federal transport ministers, who finally—seven years after the passing of the Disability Discrimination Act—have succeeded in formulating section 31 standards as they relate to transport. These standards have been warmly welcomed by the disability community, and there is a very good reason for that: they were formulated with the input, consultation and consideration of people with disabilities. They will, I expect, be warmly received by people on all sides of this House.

Apart from the capacity of the Disability Discrimination Act to have these standards or regulations made, there is also a capacity for the Disability Discrimination Commissioner, under section 67(i), to:

examine enactments, and (when requested to do so by the Minister) proposed enactments, for the purpose of ascertaining whether the enactments or proposed enactments are, or would be, inconsistent with or contrary to the objects of this Act, and to report to the Minister the results of any such examination.

I think it is appropriate to ask the government: has such an inquiry been directed to the Acting Disability Discrimination Commissioner in relation to this issue we are debating today, and if not, why wasn't that done? Of all the options that are contained within the Disability Discrimination Act, why is it that the government has chosen the biggest stick to crack the smallest nut?

State governments have hardly been overwhelmed by vexatious and frivolous claims from people with disabilities, so why the imperative to bulldozer through these regulations or regulations of this type? Put simply, there is never a reason not to consult with people who are affected—in this case, people who have disabilities. On one level it is a matter of simple respect, on another it is a matter of good public policy making and on another it is a matter of ensuring the best possible outcome and a degree of involvement that ensures that people who are affected are able to feel confident that all issues that may be relevant to them have been taken into account.

In summary, this motion is meant to send the government back to the drawing board. If the Senate supports the motion, that will be its effect. I think it will also send a message to the government—certainly from the Democrats' point of view—that they should consult more with people with disabilities. It is not adequate to simply say you have spoken to your state government counterparts. We suggest also that the government make better use of the public expertise of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission before regulations such as these are presented in this chamber in the future.

talk.start.para: —I do not intend to take a great deal of time today on this disability discrimination motion, but I do want to voice my concern and sadness that this disallowance motion has had to be brought on. It has had to be brought on because the Attorney-General thinks that consultation is not necessary. That is a real worry. This is a national government. We are trying to bring about national standards, and we are trying to have some commonality apply between all of the states. It is nearly a century since we became a federation. We had hoped—and we would have expected—that gone were the days where disability legislation regulations went back to the days of the old rail system where each state had its own gauge. This government obviously does not care about doing anything, and it is not taking any action, to enable some commonality so that people can move between states knowing that they are going to be subjected to the same regulations and the same laws.

speech.para: The minister has indicated in discussions with the Labor Party that his office does not regard it as the Commonwealth's responsibility to consult on these matters. When the government are bringing in or amending Commonwealth legislation and regulations they have a responsibility to consult with the states and with the groups which are involved and affected by their actions. They have chosen not to do that. That is a gross abrogation of the government's responsibility to people in this country.

I note that several pieces of legislation within these regulations come from my own state. They appear to be minor. The groups that are involved with the provision of disability services regard them as probably unintended consequences. If the minister and the government were being responsible, as they should be, they would know that unintended consequences can easily occur. When you are busily involved with some project you can look at the main game and think that it looks good, but it is like proofreading and editing scripts: you look at it and you think it is fine, but a fresh set of eyes can pick up some small problem that can change the whole thing dramatically. It would appear that this government has not even bothered to do that and, as I said, that is an abrogation of its responsibilities and its duty of care to people with disabilities and their families.

The Disability Discrimination Act has been in force for a number of years. It is part of a whole raft of legislation that has been introduced in the last 10 years to reform the area of disability services. When I came back to this place in 1990, one of the first inquiries I was on, as a member of the Standing Committee on Community Affairs, was a review into employment services and options for people with disabilities. Before the federal government and the South Australian government look at this any further—and it is in the area of employment that this regulation is causing the most concern—they should go back and read that community affairs committee report and understand the importance of employment to people with disabilities and the importance of receiving adequate recompense for the work that they are doing.

It would appear from these regulations that the South Australian government will allow sheltered workshops to continue with the same old practices that have been going on for 20 or 30 years and will not look to doing anything to renew, to revitalise and to improve the employment prospects and opportunities for people with disabilities. This is an absolute shame. I have very a clear recollection of evidence and submissions from that inquiry of how important people with disabilities felt it was to be able to go to work and for their work to be integrated into the work of the mainstream workplace. I shall never forget a young man in Sydney who was working with assistance as the only person with a disability in an able-bodied workplace and his delight at being able to earn a wage that was not the pension and being able to live independently, albeit with assistance. He said that the best thing about all of this was that he actually paid tax. The rest of us raised our eyebrows, but to this person with a disability the fact that he paid tax indicated to him that he was the same as everybody else.

It is very important that we recognise that the desires and aspirations of people with disabilities are very similar to ours. They want to live independently. They want to do many of the things that most of us here do. They want to work, and they do not want to be placed in work situations where they do not feel their contribution is valued. This is a vitally important point for people to understand. If you are making laws and amendments or having anything to do with changes to the laws that relate to people with disabilities, it is important to recognise that, as far as possible, people with disabilities want to be treated the same as everybody else.

Over the years we have seen the changes that have taken place in accommodation—the move away from institutionalised accommodation into group homes and supported accommodation. That was initially greeted with cries of horror and, particularly on the part of parents of people with disabilities, concern as to how they would cope with being removed from the gentle cocoon that the family wanted to put them into, where they could nurture them and not treat them like everybody else. We also heard the cries of horror when it was suggested that people with disabilities should actually be encouraged to try to participate in the workplace, albeit with assistance. We do not want to see any reversal of those improvements that have been made.

People with disabilities, and their peak bodies, have to be consulted. Not to do so is to treat them like second-class citizens and to dismiss the fact that they have the same rights as everybody else. Just because somebody does not look or sound like you or me does not mean that they do not have the same rights that you or I have to access to accommodation, access to employment and to undertake lots of activities, including marriage and, if it is possible, having children, if that is their wish. These are all very confronting issues for some people to have to address, but we must not discriminate against people with disabilities.

Sometimes it is very hard to define what is a disability. A number of us here require glasses to see. I probably could not see you, Madam Acting Deputy President, if I did not have my glasses on. Is that a disability? Where in the spectrum of disability does one disability become acceptable and another not acceptable? We really do have to look very carefully at how we treat people with disabilities, how we care for them and how we respond to their needs. For the most part, their needs are the same as ours, but in some areas their needs will be greater than ours.

We cannot afford to discriminate against some people with disabilities. Discrimination occurs when only a small number of people with a problem are affected. If everybody has to abide by those regulations and laws, whether they have a disability or not, then it is not discriminatory. If the whole of the community has to abide by something, then it will probably not be discriminatory. But where you are lining somebody up because they are different in some way, then you really do have a problem.

I am concerned that this government has failed to see that it has a responsibility to consult, discuss and negotiate, and I would suggest that this has led to a lot of the problems that we are seeing today. I know from other speakers that the Disability Discrimination Amendment Regulations 1999 (No.1) may be disallowed not because people are happy to do so but because they have concerns about some aspects and they have concerns about the government's failure to consult. If the government wants to bring these regulations in, I would urge it to, first of all, undertake a very serious and genuine round of consultations. The peak bodies and the people themselves are out there ready, willing and able to consult and negotiate. But the Attorney-General and his department have, by all accounts, chosen not to, and for that I think they stand condemned.

As I say, people with disabilities are no different from you or me and therefore they should not be discriminated against. Just as you or I would expect to be consulted and involved in things that affect our future—and we would certainly be demanding a say—so too do people with disabilities have that right. I certainly support this disallowance motion.

talk.start.para: —in reply—In closing this debate on the Disability Discrimination Amendment Regulations 1999 (No.1), I would like to thank all honourable senators who have contributed to what has been a very interesting and constructive debate today. I would like to go through some of the points that have been mentioned by other senators and then go back to some of the main issues that are driving this disallowance motion today.

speech.para: First of all, I would like very much to thank the opposition for indicating their support for the disallowance motion. I realise that there are issues of varying complexity within the ambit of this particular disallowance motion and I also realise that part of the problem was the inability to separate out some of the elements within the regulations which could have been supported.

There was mention of the Disability Discrimination Act and the ability of the original act to allow the handing back of powers. The fact that the act allows it is not an argument for what we see now. When did the act allow it? Why now, and why not with proper process? It has been argued very cogently that, if they had wanted to, there has been time for the states and the Commonwealth government, particularly the Commonwealth minister, to engage in proper process. It makes no sense to put this through at this stage without any of that process having taken place.

Senator Vanstone argued—and it seemed to be the main thrust of her argument—that this matter is the responsibility of the states and territories. This government has no problems with introducing draconian laws and removing rights in relation to things such as industrial relations. This government has no problems with transferring money from the public sector to the private sector in relation to schools. This government does not have any problem with interfering with what it thinks are states areas, such as education, housing and so on, where it is a matter of removing rights and responsibilities. It is quite happy to deal with legislation provided it can walk backwards from its responsibilities. It is not a matter of whether these are Commonwealth powers; it is not a matter of whether these are Commonwealth responsibilities. Remember, this is a Commonwealth act. The states cannot administer a Commonwealth act: it is the Commonwealth's responsibility.

Senator Vanstone said that the requests for prescription were received from several states and territories. She also said that there was, if you like, an ambit claim from the states. The successful states, using some people's jargon—some people would say they were the unsuccessful states—were South Australia and New South Wales. We have not heard from the minister, we have not heard from Senator Vanstone today and we have not heard—and the groups involved have not heard—from the Attorney-General on what basis that decision was made. If there was an ambit claim of lots of laws that the various states threw into the basket, what was the process and what was the basis upon which some of those regulations were accepted as being thrown in for prescription and others were not? We are still left in the dark as to what that process was.

We understand that the act only requires consultation by state ministers. We also understand that there are lots of acts that require certain people to be consulted. That in no way says that it is the correct practice not to consult with relevant parties. Can you imagine dealing with a tax act or a corporate bill? We have had examples in relation to the ANTS package. There is no way this government would consider introducing a bill which interacted in any way with corporate Australia without consulting fully with all of the interested bodies. There is no way that those interested bodies would not come and speak to the Commonwealth. Can you imagine a Commonwealth minister from the coalition refusing to speak to those bodies and saying, `Look, I'm sorry. There is legislation about this kind of matter in the states and we are not going to talk to you'? Ministers would not say that.

It seems to me that in this particular case this very weak excuse is being used simply because it is a matter on which the Commonwealth government is having difficulty coming to any ethical decisions. So it has handballed it. As Senator Vanstone mentioned, the states put in the ambit claim. They did not make the final decision: it was the Commonwealth that made the final decision. Any reasonable, responsible government would then take the responsibility for that decision. What were the reasons? Has the government given them? No, it has not. It is not, I believe, the right thing to do to use an odd concept of states right as a catch-all for lack of consultation and proper process.

Senator Vanstone, to reinforce her point, used education and said that the proper operation of the South Australian education system is, in the end, the responsibility of the South Australian government. The human rights obligations and responsibilities—that is, those international obligations to which Australia is a signatory—were not signed specifically by negotiators from the states: they were signed by the Commonwealth. Therefore, if what we are doing is making sure that basic human rights and basic international agreements are adhered to, it is not the proper thing to then expect that it is the South Australian government that should be the only one involved in consultation.

It may well be true—and it seems to me from the contributions from various senators that they have indications that it is true—that the state governments have not done their job in terms of consultation, but that is no excuse for the Commonwealth to put their hands behind their back and say, `Well, we're not going to either.' Here we have a situation where the final decision was the Commonwealth's and in some ways the state governments will say that that final decision was out of their hands. They may well be right. We know the Commonwealth government are quite prepared to make decisions removing or changing workers rights. Therefore, it is not valid to suggest that, when it comes to workers rights, there is no power or ability for the Commonwealth to be involved.

Senator Quirke gave a very moving example of special schools and the choices, or lack of choices, that may be available now and the fewer choices that may be available should this legislation go through, considering the pressure that is being put on states to reduce costs, the economic rationalists and the pressure that comes from things like competition policy and each school and each sector having to `make a profit'. I believe the pressure on the states to get out of those responsibilities will be huge. Perhaps they will have to lump various people with various needs into certain institutions without being able to see whether it might be more appropriate for some of those students to be in mainstream schools with the students in those schools being able to see the benefits of sharing with those people who have different abilities from their own. I believe there are benefits on both sides.

Senator Gibbs talked about the Attorney-General's neglect of ministerial responsibility and emphasised the lack of consultation. Talking about disability, we might say that this legislation is in itself an example of discrimination. Where a minister would in most cases see the necessity of consulting with relevant groups to get feedback from the very people who are likely to be most affected, in this case that minister has not been able to bring himself to talk to those people. We can only ask why. Contrast this, as Senator Gibbs did, with the GST consultation. But even within the consultation in the ANTS package there are certain people the government has chosen to consult and other people the government has chosen to turn its back on.

Senator Bolkus criticised the guaranteeing base for funding to states with no monitoring and oversight. We could add to the list. To education we can add environment. This government is moving away from its environmental responsibilities and here we have a situation where it is moving away from its human rights responsibilities. I believe there is no point in the Senate assisting and abetting the removal of the Commonwealth's connection with its responsibilities for the money they are spending and for the responsibilities they have signed up to in terms of international agreements. Senator Bolkus quite rightly said that what we would be doing would be laying down conditions for further abdication of Commonwealth responsibilities.

I thank Senator Bartlett for his contribution. He stood in at short notice for Senator Allison, who was otherwise engaged in consultations of a different sort. I thank the Democrats as joint movers of this motion. Senator West, from the opposition, talked about a report from the Standing Committee on Community Affairs specifically about disabilities and issues in relation to disabilities and indicated that the government is clearly ignoring the report and the outcomes from the findings of that committee. One can only wonder who the government was listening to—who the Attorney-General thought he was representing in this case.

I return to the report that I tabled with the assistance of honourable senators here and the report from the Australian Psychiatric Disability Coalition and the National Council on Intellectual Disability. They talked of people with disabilities and their representatives not being consulted. As they mention, the Commonwealth Disability Discrimination Act is an act of parliament. Their report says:

The power contained in the DDA to make regulations is the responsibility of the Commonwealth Attorney General. In the final analysis, the responsibility for making of such regulations lies with the Commonwealth Attorney General. The Commonwealth Attorney General's refusal to discuss the regulations with the community and the disability sector is a neglect of his Ministerial responsibility and accountability.
It was not specifically required in the act, but this is the least one could expect. It goes on to say:
The legislation is therefore presented to parliament without any publicly known rationale, community discussion or input.

Not only did the Attorney-General not talk to these groups but he did not provide any rationale at all for the basis of the decision—and neither did Senator Vanstone today. Senator Vanstone's only argument was that it was concerned with state powers and this was rightly the role of states. The states did not provide a rationale and now neither has the Commonwealth. The report says:

The move to prescribe state legislation and regulations without consultation suggests that state responsibility to ensure that state legislation is consistent with disability discrimination legislation is being ignored.

If the states are ignoring it, it is no excuse for the Commonwealth to do so as well. The Greens (WA) believe, as everybody does, that the preparation of regulations should be in line with the current standards of the Disability Discrimination Act. The Australian Psychiatric Disability Coalition and the National Council on Intellectual Disability argue that section 31 of the DDA provides the Attorney- General with the ability to formulate standards to be known as disability standards in relation to education, employment, transport, accommodation and Commonwealth laws and programs. But they believe that the delegation legislation prepared by the Commonwealth Attorney-General is:

. . . in direct conflict with the current processes to develop disability standards. The process to develop disability standards involves representation from people with disabilities and relevant community, industry and government representatives.

So you have the Attorney-General with the power in the legislation to develop standards, and in this process this minister has turned away from that and is pretending that, even though he has this power and—I would say—this responsibility, he does not have to abide by it. Quite clearly, the High Court supports the contention that all Australian law should be subject to human rights standards. Why should disability standards be any less than any other standards?

I agree that this government is prepared to turn its back on any standards that Australia has signed up to on an international level. But this exacerbates the existing differences in society. In the workplace it is the difference in power between workers and people being treated for a mental illness. I quote again from this report:
The stigma and assumptions surrounding mental illness make people with such a disorder a most vulnerable group in need of as much protection as can be given.

Yet in this instance we are not giving more protection; we are giving less. It behoves the Senate to listen to the words that have been given to us today. Again I thank all honourable senators for their valuable contributions. I urge the government to consider carefully what has been said today and accept this disallowance motion. You should make sure that you do it right the next time and make sure that your very act of legislation is not in itself a discrimination against those very people that you should be looking after. I commend the disallowance motion to the Senate.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Margetts's ) be agreed to.

division.result.para: Question so resolved in the negative.

National Residue Survey (Excise) Levy Amendment Bill 1998

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed.

talk.start.para: —The Democrats have grave concerns with the Broadcasting Services Amendment (Online Services) Bill 1999 . We are still a little unsure as to what is driving the government in the implementation of this legislation, which we consider unworkable and as having undesirable aspects in relation to this regulatory regime. This morning, in discussing the exemption of this bill from the cut-off, I referred to the government's failure to establish a need for this legislation and its inability to substantiate some of the reasons it has put forward for this legislation, in particular in relation to community concerns. Since the government has no intention to change its strategy on this proposal at this late stage, I will take this opportunity to outline the Democrats' continuing concerns with this bill and the government's approach.

speech.para: Before outlining the Democrat concerns, I remind the Senate—particularly in light of Senator Tierney's contribution to this debate—that the Democrats are not advocates of unsuitable Internet material being made available to minors. That view is probably reflected among all honourable senators in this place. However, we are unable to countenance the markedly different treatment of similar materials published in different media. This is an important point for us in debating this legislation. The Democrats do not advocate an entirely laissez-faire approach to the regulation of Internet content, but clearly we have major concerns with the mechanisms proposed by the government and the extent of their interference in legitimate expression.

As we have pointed out on numerous previous occasions, our concerns are divided primarily into two main groups. The first of these relates to the unworkability of the proposals. In particular, we are opposed to the creation of a system of regulation which has no hope of preventing access to inappropriate materials. The very intention of the legislation is to block or stop what is considered inappropriate material. Why create a regulatory regime that does not necessarily have the ability to do just that?

The bill addresses content published on Australian servers and overseas servers in markedly different ways. For Australian content, the bill provides a regime that can work, although at significant cost to the Australian Internet industry. There are major concerns about the interaction between the ABA as the peak regulatory authority and the use of industry codes to create enforcement mechanisms in tune with the legislation. But the big problems with the workability of this proposed legislation are linked to the problem of regulating Internet behaviour beyond our jurisdiction. By now it is recognised in most countries that regulation of the Internet is a jurisdictional problem probably without peer. The jurisdictional problem obviously arises in relation to the treatment of material that originates overseas.

However, instead of developing an approach which would have the possibility of preventing the access of minors to inappropriate material, the government seems to have taken a leaf out of the story of King Canute. Standing on Australia's metaphorical shore and demanding that the tide of content turn back seems a bit far-fetched as a legislative response to Internet regulation. But this is actually what the government is envisaging. For materials hosted overseas the legislation demands that Internet service providers take `reasonable steps to block access to content which would be classified as inappropriate'. I think we should draw the Senate's attention to remarks by the government on this aspect of the legislation. In press releases, media interviews and indeed during the Senate committee process, the government has referred to technical feasibility as the test, but contrary to repeated assurances this is not the test to be applied in the legislation. Overwhelming evidence has been provided showing that the blocking of materials is going to be costly to the Australian Internet industry—both directly and indirectly. More significantly, evidence was provided to the committee investigating this bill which indicated that the blocking mechanisms and approaches suggested were technically flawed. Senator Tierney alluded to some of that evidence as well.

The performance implications are very serious and the proposed blocking would be easily circumvented. Evidence on the performance of blocking technologies indicated overwhelmingly that they were more successful the closer to the user they were implemented. The overall conclusion in evidence presented to the committee in the CSIRO report is:
Content blocking implemented purely by technological means will be ineffective.

The other area of broad concern that the Australian Democrats have with the proposed legislation is the undesirable aspect of many aspects of the proposed content control regime. I have listed some of these concerns before, but I reiterate them for the purpose of this debate. They include: the failure to address civil liberties concerns relating to privacy and freedom of speech and expres sion, the creation of broad discretions and uncertain law enforcement provisions, the different treatment of materials in different media, the almost certain adverse impact on the Internet industry in Australia, the likely deleterious impact on the information economy in Australia and the failure to address concerns about the likelihood of inappropriate and inadvertent blocking of materials and related issues. I will expand on some of these issues of concern.

The Democrats feel compelled to remind the parliament of the place of free speech in our system of government. We must be aware that freedom of speech is what is left after the boundaries have been defined by the courts and the parliament. We do not believe that the government has met the onus required to justify the restrictions proposed under the legislation. During the committee process the comparison was drawn between the proposed regime and the content controls implemented in other countries not often classed as liberal democracies. It should be noted that recent news reports suggest that Canada has now abandoned previous attempts to control content.

We are very concerned about the legal construction of the legislation. In this context, our main concern relates to the broad problem of creating an unenforceable law. We have already indicated that the failure of this unworkable law might lead to further and perhaps more punitive demands for Internet content control. There is also the concern that a largely unenforceable law will lead to undermined confidence in government and further distrust from the Internet community. Believe me, in evidence before the committee and in the many faxes, phone calls and emails we have received from the industry, both in this country and overseas, there is already a level of distrust of this government and uncertainty in those important sectors.

The different treatment of like content also deserves attention. The government has made it quite clear that it views the Internet as analogous to existing media. I note that this bill draws on broadcasting and narrowcasting analogies to explain some of its provisions. The government continually denies the special nature of Internet publishing processes. Internet content is made available by huge numbers of publishers. It is made available on a pull or demand driven model: users must explicitly request material before it is provided. As one of only a few countries in the world with content controls, Australia would become a less desirable place to host or develop Internet content. This and other indirect economic costs would be likely to have significant impact on the development of the whole Internet industry in Australia. Surely that industry is something that we want to encourage and support, not clamp down on or quash. This is in addition to the direct costs of enforcement which I have already referred to.

Alternatives—relying on voluntary client-side blocking, education and adult responsibility—would be unlikely to have such a detrimental impact on the development of the information economy in Australia. It is hard to imagine any group that would benefit economically, except perhaps the multinational creators of family content. The likely shake-up in the Australian Internet industry would lead to a reduction in the diversity and coverage of Internet service providers in Australia. The Democrats view this as a very unfortunate outcome generally but particularly unfortunate for regional and country users of Internet facilities.

Evidence was also given at the Senate select committee about a number of inconsistencies in the funding of the content regulation mechanisms. In particular, the Democrats would like to draw attention to the vastly different classification regimes proposed by the government in the bill for Internet content and the simultaneous move to a user-pays system in film and video classification.

Another of the big concerns about the government's proposal is the need to regulate the use and operation of any filtering technologies. These concerns apply to both client-side and service provider based filtering. Numerous cases and studies confirm that content filters often block material which it would actually be desirable to make available—it is inadvertent blocking of those materials.

Concerns have been raised about the blocking of sites referring to, say, health issues such as breast cancer. Gay and lesbian sites, especially those for teenagers, are blocked by most filtering programs. Other examples of sites that are blocked include: the anti-racism site, HateWatch; safe sex sites; safe drug use sites; drug sites about feminism; and sites about alternative politics. A very recent analysis of one of the government's favoured technologies has revealed the blocking of the National Party home page and the Mick's Whips e-commerce site. I note in passing that this site has often been used by the leader of the National Party as an example of the success of Australia's information economy. Imagine blocking a National Party home page!

The Australian Democrats believe that any use of filters, whether client-side or ISP based, must be regulated to prevent the imposition of value systems which are not explicit. Users must know exactly what will be blocked and alternatives must be made available which do not promulgate narrow American family values. That is not meant to be an adverse reflection on American society, but just a reflection on where a lot of the content is coming from. Systems which are based on complex weighting schemes, such as that provided by Clairview as an example, should only be employed after a rigorous and open examination of the inherent assumptions that are being made about content. Blocking lists and weighting schemes must be fully disclosed to prevent abuse. In a democracy, censorship mechanisms cannot be as protected as trade secrets.

Given the time available, I would now like to make it very clear what the Democrat position is on this bill. We do not advocate unsuitable Internet material being made available to minors. As I said before, I do not believe any senator or member in this place would advocate such a position. That is not a point of disagreement in this debate. We oppose the restriction of adult access to material which would generally be acceptable to reasonable adults. We oppose the restriction of adult access to Internet content where that content is available in different media. There is no reason for the kind of material that is currently available to adults in a different medium to be blocked on the Internet specifically.

We have found very little evidence of the so-called overwhelming community concern claimed by government as the motivation for this legislation. In fact, evidence before the Senate committee indicated that the Australian public is far more concerned about inappropriate censorship. Evidence also indicates that extreme violence and racism are actually of greater concern than explicit sexual material. Internet users have a number of serious and legitimate concerns about Internet regulation, including hate speech, vilification, defamation, gambling, privacy, security, encryption and the legality of electronic transactions. These issues are not addressed in this bill.

These issues have also not been debated at any length in the Senate select committee, which has responsibility for investigating issues to do with information technology. These issues were indicated by many witnesses as being of more concern than, for example, monitoring or clamping down on sexually explicit material. Perhaps we should be focusing on these areas in the burgeoning information economy as opposed to legislation of this nature.

The government has not demonstrated any problems with the use of existing legislative provisions for dealing with inappropriate content, including section 85ZE of the Crimes Act 1914—which, of course, is a mechanism which is already in place for dealing with illegal or illicit content that may be online. The Democrats remain very concerned about the government's unwillingness to address some of the civil liberties issues raised by this bill. Restrictions on freedom of speech and imprecise enforcement provisions—in some cases privatising law enforcement functions—are serious and should not be dismissed lightly. This bill proposes a scheme of content regulation which treats the Internet very differently from analogous media. Content which is legal in one medium could actually be considered illegal in another.

para.inline: Sitting suspended from 6.30 p.m. to 7.30 p.m.

talk.start.para: —Before the dinner break, I was explaining the Democrats' concerns about this bill, which fall into two categories: philosophical, that is, it may be a constraint on certain civil liberties in a democracy, such as freedom of speech and expression; and its workability, that is, the technical feasibility of the legislation. I was just concluding by articulating clearly to the chamber, for the record, the Democrats' concerns.

speech.para: We do not believe that Internet content regulation should result in a medium which is brought down to a lowest common denominator. Regulation must take into account the diversity of the Internet and the legitimate and responsible use of that medium by adults. If the bill is to proceed, it should include some guarantees of the privacy of both transactions and the personal details of Internet users. The possibility of logging transactions via proxies would result in a major invasion of privacy, in our opinion.

The evidence overwhelmingly suggests that the proposal to block overseas Internet content is technically flawed. There are major performance implications, and blocking is able to be circumvented. In our opinion, that would have major economic consequences. The Democrats are concerned about inappropriate and inadvertent blocking. This concern applies generally to filters, but of course it is of particular concern where blocking is compulsory. Blocking lists used in filters should be fully disclosed. Secret lists of which materials are to be blocked could lead to abuse, so that whole process must be transparent. Any censorship in a liberal democracy, as I have stated for the record, must be open and it must be accountable.

The creation of an unenforceable law, such as the provisions blocking overseas content, is highly undesirable. The Democrats have numerous concerns about the drafting of the bill as it has been presented to the committee. These include broad discretions, harsh penalties, undefined terms and the possible abuse of provisions. We believe that self-regulation and co-regulation need to be more carefully investigated in the context of content regulation.

Client-side filtering technologies and differentiated Internet services offer a workable alternative to blocking materials at the source or in transit. Client-side technologies need to be regulated to ensure that appropriate content is not inappropriately or inadvertently blocked. Users need to be fully aware of the assumptions and of the models that are being used to block content.

The Democrats believe that adult responsibility should be a central component of any attempt to control the way in which young people use the Internet. The Australian Democrats would support a system of Internet content regulation that was based on empowerment of responsible adults rather than a command and control censorship mechanism. This would need to include education and the availability of client-side filtering technologies.

The Democrats regret the sensationalist way in which the government has labelled critics of this proposed legislation, including a number of those organisations and witnesses that appeared before the Senate select committee. We believe that this bill has been prepared with undue haste and that consideration should be given to alternative proposals that are based on the education and the empowerment of users, as well as on an understanding of the responsibility of those supervising Internet access for young people. Certainly the Democrats agree that there is a need to address the issue of Internet content, but we have serious problems with the proposals currently before us and we do not believe that the hurried process has been appropriate.

As I said, we have grave concerns about this legislation on two grounds: philosophical, that is, civil liberties questions; and the feasibility and workability of the legislation. I strongly urge senators to reject the legislation before us, to enter into an examination of what would be appropriate and to do it in a way that is not rushed and not part of a trading off process in terms of other legislation or of cross-trading on other issues. Then we could have a regulatory system that suited all users of the Internet but that did not quash, thwart, undermine or erode the burgeoning information economy in Australia.

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak as part of the opposition's response to what is a very quick bill—poorly drafted and brought in here with undue haste. A number of senators were on the committee examining this bill, and they brought down the report which was tabled earlier this month. I congratulate them on grappling with the number of issues in the short time they were given. The issues in the report only begin the debate; they do not conclude the debate.

speech.para: The opposition has already made it clear that we believe this bill is fundamentally flawed and that it should be significantly amended. My colleague Senator Bishop has indicated the moving of a second reading amendment that reflects our grave concerns about the sloppy way in which this bill has been brought forward and drafted. We have also indicated there will be a number of other technical amendments to the provisions. Some of the draconian provisions in this bill should be amended.

We have outlined that we would support a review of the bill, if it were to be carried by the Senate, and a sunset clause that this bill would last no more than three years and that it would lapse unless the Senate and the Australian parliament reintroduced a bill after ministerial review and further debate. The opposition has made it clear that, in relation to the Internet and all the ancillary services it provides, it is crazy to try to define legislation to regulate the Internet forever and a day when the technology is changing so rapidly.
