I do not think we should in any way shy away from taking action just because no-one else has gone down this path. In fact, it has been put to me that, if we get it right, this may well be a much more sensible model than that which has been tried in some other places.

talk.start.para: —I also ask whether the government can provide the committee with any information that talks about community concerns and community attitudes. In his comments, the minister talked about a survey from overseas that looked at community concern about regulation. I do not mean to misrepresent the example the minister gave, but I would like to draw his attention to some of the community opinions about censorship, and Internet censorship in particular, that have been made available to us. It is the case that in Australia community opinion has been surveyed.

speech.para: I am not sure what information the government has at its disposal, as opposed to relying on American surveys, but I still contend that there was no information before the inquiry from the government that would indicate that the broader community are in favour of a punitive or even unworkable regime. Most recently, a survey by the Sunday program on 25 April 1999 posed the following questions: `Which of the following are you most concerned about: sex and nudity on television, violence on television, or senators telling us what we can watch?' I acknowledge the distinction between television and the Internet, but I think it was quite telling that the results of the survey indicated that four per cent of the respondents were concerned about sex and nudity, 12 per cent were concerned about violence, and 84 per cent were concerned about senators telling us what we can and cannot watch. I am wondering what the government's response is to those figures.

Another survey, by the Eros Foundation, was carried out by Roy Morgan in early 1999. The results of that survey clearly demonstrate some significant conclusions—again across broader media. Findings showed that a clear majority of adults were in favour of the film Lolita being available for viewing by adults. The survey indicated, once again, an overwhelming opposition to political interference in the classification process.

There was also a survey by www.consult, undertaken in January and February this year, of Australian Internet users. Around 25,000 surveys were submitted. One of the questions in the survey was: `Do you think the government should censor the Internet?' In reply, 9.9 per cent of respondents chose the option `I think the government should censor the Internet'; 62.5 per cent chose `I think parents should be responsible for their kids' Internet use'; 22.2 per cent chose `I don't think anyone should censor the Internet'; 4.1 per cent chose, `I don't care'; and 0.6 per cent of respondents did not respond to the particular question.

A number of polls have been conducted by Radio National, and one was done by the Age. Again these were across different media and I acknowledge—through you, Madam Temporary Chairman to the minister—that they were not specific to the Internet. But I am really curious to see what substantiation there is of the government's statement of reasons that there is overwhelming community concern.

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —I have seen some of those surveys and most of them are mickey mouse. The one that you referred to about senators telling us what to do was basically the tag line of a very one-sided effort by the Channel Nine Sunday program several weeks back. I would not for a moment take it seriously. To ask someone, `Are you in favour of senators telling you how to lead your lives or what to watch?'—this was the third question; I forget what the first and second were—is preposterous. It has got nothing at all to do with the issues at hand. I would be very surprised if many people would put their hands up and say, `I am in favour of senators—or anyone else—telling me what to do.' That tells you nothing at all about whether parents have legitimate or even unfounded concerns about what their children might be watching.

speech.para: I would have thought the best way of gauging community concern is to look at what the reaction has been since this legislation was first mooted, having regard to the fact that this has been an ongoing issue over a matter of years. There have certainly been surveys that have shown that one of the big hesitation points for people having PCs in their homes or accessing the Internet is that they are concerned about what they might come across or what their children might come across. If the concerns were other than very narrowly based, you would certainly have expected a lot more rank and file outcries than I have come across.

You will always find industry speaking self-interestedly; it is not confined to this particular industry. Some of the surveys that simply ask users what they think remind me very much of Wired magazine back in the early 1990s which ran this sort of line constantly. You would have loved it, Senator Stott Despoja. It appealed to all the yuppies who regarded themselves as being the next generation. They did not believe in any form of controls. They thought the Internet was the wild frontier, that it was the best place to be and that everyone ought to get their hands off. And they ran this line for some years. Eventually, when they got around to doing a survey, they found out that even their own subscribers had the same views as mainstream America, and that was, `Yes, we do want you to intervene, we do want you to protect our personal privacy, we do not want to come across offensive material and we do want you to treat it as much as possible the way that you would treat the physical world.'

A few self-interested industry surveys, particularly those of the civil libertarians, have played a very superficial role in this whole debate, aided and abetted by some journalists who have taken the lazy way out and not bothered to read the provisions of the bill but have made sweeping generalisations about, `Isn't it outrageous that someone should be in there trying to regulate our lives?' I read one today in the Canberra Times, which said something like `Whether or not parents should be concerned about the safety of their children on the Internet, the fact remains' and away it went with the usual over-the-top rhetoric. So when people are not prepared to address the issues and to ask whether it is a matter of serious concern and whether something should be done about it rather than whether they can manufacture a way to express their outrage in such a way that they kill off the bill then you will not have a sensible discussion on the subject. I am very confident that the response of the parties in this chamber is in itself an indication.

If you honestly thought that there was a huge groundswell of opinion out there that was violently opposed to what we were doing, don't you think we would have heard a lot more about it in this chamber and in the other chamber? You have not. In fact, I think we even heard Senator Brown saying that in principle he supported doing something. He then of course went off on his usual red herring about casinos. That may be a separate and legitimate issue, but it has nothing to do with whether or not you ought to be trying to restrict access to offensive material on the Internet. When we last had this debate in this chamber, I detected cross-party support for the proposition that we ought to do what we can. That is what we were elected to do, and I certainly have not seen any community response that would say that we are on anything other than the right track.

talk.start.para: —I want to follow up with some questions arising out of your answers, Minister. You mentioned the response to the Wired magazine survey in the US and identified the issue of personal privacy as one of grave concern to online citizens, amongst other things. Why is it that your government has chosen to legislate to deal with the Internet in this way whilst not proceeding with the appropriate privacy protections that have been mooted for some time now with respect to electronic information about citizens? Further, you make comments about the civil libertarians having not bothered to involve themselves in this debate, when one of the greatest difficulties to date has been the time frame put forward by your government. How outrageous it is for you to stand up and criticise the Australian community for lack of input or substandard contribution to this debate when you have pushed it forward so rapidly in the environment of the inquiry and when the Select Committee on Information Technologies had profound difficulty trying to structure a series of hearings and get the appropriate number and range of witnesses that were necessary to explore these issues in full in time to suit your agenda.

speech.para: It is worth noting that the IT select committee has a majority of government members and with the support of Senator Harradine has the ability to determine its agenda and timetable. That is what occurred. You have had complete control of this timetable and you have condensed public discussion and debate under the auspices of that inquiry and in the public arena to a point where people have not had the opportunity to contribute in a full way—in a way that they are demanding and in a way that you have rejected—and that is because you have chosen to compress the time frame and not allow the debate to develop.

I suspect that had you put in place a realistic timetable through the course of this debate, had you put this bill on the table and allowed even just the typical timing to occur, then the Australian community's voice would have become louder as knowledge and understanding of the implications of this bill permeated beyond the online community and into the general community—those, I hasten to add, who are not online largely through some neglect of your party's commitment to promoting equity of access for all Australians to the Internet.

The issue of other legislation that is required to facilitate the addressing of both social and economic implications of the Internet takes me back to the question that I asked. At what point does your government intend to legislate for the protection of privacy of information relating to citizens of this country? Why is it that you have chosen not to legislate in that area prior to this bill coming forward? Why is it that, rather than facilitating the growth of the online community and the online economy through legislation relating to digital signatures and other such matters, this happens to be the very first bill to be debated in this chamber with direct impact—unfortunately, in a negative way—on the online community and the online economy?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —I did not say that the civil liberties community had not been involved in the debate, and I certainly did not criticise the community for not being involved in the debate. I said that the civil liberties groups had, by and large, distinguished themselves by not condescending to detail. In other words, how long does it take you to read this bill—a couple of hours? They have had weeks to get their minds around it, if they had really wanted to. There have been hear ings galore. These are people who supposedly pride themselves on being experts in the field. By and large, they have tried to maintain a campaign at a very rhetorical level, which I do not think does justice to the concerns of the wider community, and I do not think even they pretend that it does. It might appeal to their own membership, it might be a way of getting people a bit more excited about an issue, but it does not do justice to the debate.

speech.para: As far as privacy is concerned, we are not debating privacy, but there is an Attorney-General's consultative committee that has been labouring away on that issue for quite some time, as I am sure you know. There has been almost an impasse between the American approach and the EU, and we think we are in the process of arriving at a solution that will provide the best of both. But it is not something that we are breaking our necks to legislate on just for the sake of it.

However, not only has this been the subject of other parliamentary hearings over a period of years but also it has effectively reached the point where, unless a legislative framework is put in place, there is no incentive for the industry itself to start developing those codes of practice, and it does not give them a set of principles around which to build the codes. We certainly take the view that we are moving at the appropriate pace. No doubt you and others like you would like forever—just as you have wanted to try to stall other critical pieces of legislation—but we do not think that is the right approach here, and we will be pressing ahead.

talk.start.para: —Minister, what are the implications for freedom of speech in this legislation?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —They are no more or less than any legislation, and there is an abundance of it that can curtail any absolute freedom. As you well know, real life consists of compromises in every area. No-one has the right to shout, `Fire!' in a crowded theatre, and no-one pretends that you have the right to go around defaming others. There are many limitations on freedom of speech in its absolute form; the question is whether they are justified. This bill seeks to strike the necessary balance so that people can give expression to legitimate issues and portrayals but not in such a way that they degrade humanity or that they simply purvey highly offensive or indeed illegal material which has little or no redeeming social benefit.
—I am interested in the speech that degrades humanity. I wonder if the minister could explain to the committee what he meant by that term and what limitations should be put on it.

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —I am not going to go beyond saying that this bill is all about trying to contain access to offensive or illegal material. If Senator Brown does not know what that is, then perhaps he had better get out there and have a look at some of the hundred million web sites there are around the world. There is no shortage of highly offensive material, if you want to look for it, and that is what this bill is all about.

—For example, Senator Synon, according to today's Daily Telegraph , has moved to ask the ABA to look at—presumably to remove—a reference to a lesbian relationship during an afternoon programming session. Minister, is that the sort of thing that you would like to see removed from public access?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —That has nothing to do with this bill.

—Yes, it has everything to do with the bill. What I am trying to establish here are the limitations, as the minister sees them, that should be placed on what is publicly available. The debate has of course centred on what is available to children. Senator Synon—from the minister's side of the chamber—believes that a perfectly ordinary lesbian relationship is not something that should be allowed. I ask the minister whether he agrees.

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —Again, I say that it has nothing to do with this legislation. As I understand that issue, the concern that has been expressed relates to what a spokesman from the ABA had to say about a soap that has been running now for some months.

speech.para: Progress reported.

talk.start.para: —Order! It being 9.50 p.m., I propose the question:

interjection.para: That the Senate do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: —I rise tonight to speak about national competition policy and its advantages for the Australian community. In 1995 the Labor government, supported by the coalition in opposition and all state and territory governments, implemented the most broad ranging program of micro-economic reform ever attempted in Australia to that time. It was designed to improve Australia's economic performance by bringing higher productivity to the government sector, in particular, and also to the non-corporate sector. The encouragement of competition in Australia has been a bipartisan policy in order to encourage efficiency and fairness in the community.

speech.para: The 1974 Trade Practices Act is the statute which oversees this competition. It originally only applied to incorporated business—that is, to companies only. But since 1995, through the national competition policy, the Trade Practices Act now applies to government businesses and to unincorporated businesses through the competition principles agreement and the conduct code agreement. The aim of this policy was to introduce competition to virtually all sectors of the Australian economy. Why? Because competition means reduced prices and better service for consumers and increased welfare for everybody. This is another area where some key policies and practices had been preventing Australia from reaching its economic potential. The results were inappropriate regulation and red tape and government monopolies which provided poor service and kept prices high. Those policies had weakened the incentives for people to be innovative and self-reliant.

The 1995 national competition policy reform package was a breakthrough. It provides Australia with a chance to harness resources more effectively, more efficiently and more productively. Higher productivity and economic growth are the only ways to get higher sustainable wages and better job prospects. These policies will give consumers an idea of the true cost of providing services and are also an essential guide to investments by both the private and government sectors for the benefit of all. All state and territory governments showed they were committed to it in 1995, including the coalition opposition in Canberra. We supported this policy because it was good for Australia in the long run.

Contrast this with the situation today. I remind the Senate that when Labor were in power we supported each of their four major economic reforms: freeing up the Australian dollar, freeing up the finance markets, lowering tariffs and competition policy. None of these policies were taken to the electorate before they were actioned but we, the coalition, supported them because they were good for all Australians. Contrast that with the position today and tax reform. Tax reform has been a long-term issue—Asprey in 1975, Hawke in 1986 and Hewson in 1993. Both sides of politics know that tax reform is needed in Australia. Yet, unlike our attitude when Labor were in power, they do not want to act in the long-term interests of Australia, for our children and our grandchildren. They oppose tax reform for their short-term political goals. What a shame.

But I digress. Back to competition policy, the projected gains from national competition policy are impressive. The estimates at the time were that the annual gain in real GDP would amount to about 5.5 per cent—about $30 billion a year in today's dollars. Wages were projected to be three per cent higher than they would otherwise be and it was predicted that an additional 30,000 jobs would be generated. After three years, the results are already impressive. Electricity bills in contestable markets of Sydney and Melbourne have fallen by around 30 per cent, the price per kilowatt hour is half that of non-contestable markets in Hobart and Perth, the national electricity market has been working since December last year and all users in the eastern states will be able to choose their own supplier by the year 2001.

Gas prices for major industrial users fell by 50 per cent after deregulation of the Western Australian market in 1995. Gas access charges are set to fall by 60 per cent by the year 2000 in New South Wales. The cost of international telephone calls has fallen by 50 per cent in real terms in the past six years and the cost of STD phone calls has fallen by 40 per cent over the same period. Last week Telstra announced further drops in call prices for both STD and international calls. Consumers in New South Wales have saved at least $86 million as conveyancing costs fell by 17 per cent between 1994 and 1996 when the legal profession's monopoly was removed. In Queensland, 10 of the 17 largest councils have implemented two-part tariffs for water, resulting in an average saving in water usage of 20 per cent in the first year. Rail freight rates for the Perth-Melbourne route fell by 40 per cent and service quality and transit times improved after the introduction of competition. Freight prices for grain in Western Australia dropped by 21 per cent in real terms after deregulation in 1992-93. Freight rates for coal in the Hunter Valley dropped by 25 per cent over three years and a further 10 per cent fall is scheduled in the next 12 months.

Despite the success of competition policy reforms, there are still some people, some interest groups and some politicians who would choose to abandon it. As the Productivity Commission draft report on this topic—published this month—says, there is general confusion about the causes of rural decline in both population and economic activity. The decline has been in progress for many regions of Australia for many years. The key factors behind this have been, firstly, declining terms of trade for agricultural and mining products. In agriculture, the real prices of products have been down by over half over the past 40 years. For mining products, the prices are down but by nowhere near as much as for agriculture. The second factor has been greatly increased productivity. I remind the Senate that Bert Kelly, the modest member, used to say that if you want to stop rural population decline you should ban tractors. Hence the share of agriculture and mining has dropped from 20 per cent of GDP 50 years ago to eight per cent today.

National competition policy brings the Trade Practices Act to government monopolies, such as energy and transport, which had been characterised in the past by poor management, overmanning, poor service and inappropriate pricing. It also provides for access reform for common infrastructure such as rail and pipelines. It also proposes, and is implementing, structural reform of government businesses. For instance, New South Wales rail is broken up into seven parts and the Victorian ports authority has also been broken up. Another key direction is the review of anticompetition legislation.

As both the National Competition Council and the Productivity Commission have pointed out, better communication of the aims of national competition policy are required. The results are often forgotten. The lower prices and the better service are just taken for granted. It behoves all of us as politicians to make sure that we take every opportunity to let the community know of the benefits of competition and its extension to government and other enterprises. Everyone will be better off.

Australia must continue to adapt to change. We are a small fish in a big ocean and if we want our children and our grandchildren to prosper we must have a more competitive economy. Finally, where changes are necessary, governments must strive to be compassionate with people or groups that are affected by change. In conclusion, I commend to the Senate the annual report of the National Competition Council and the draft report of the Productivity Commission on the impact of competition policy and reforms on rural and regional Australia. I congratulate both of those organisations on the work they have done.

subdebateinfo.title: Shortage of Doctors in Rural Australia

talk.start.para: —The shortage of doctors in rural and remote regions of Australia is a complex problem that the Howard government has been tackling on many fronts with some success. In 1998 there was an increase of 4.1 per cent in the numbers of doctors in rural areas. However, the problem is far from being solved. Only 16 per cent of doctors work in rural areas while 30 per cent of the population lives in these areas. The problem has an added urgency when one discovers that an estimated 22 per cent of those doctors working in rural areas will retire in the next 10 years and on average doctors working in rural practice only stay for two years.

speech.para: It is interesting to compare the experience of the more rural and remote provinces of Canada with what we are trying to do in Australia. Canada has similar problems to Australia, with the bulk of the population concentrated in their southern cities and with similar small rural farming communities as well as isolated centres in their remote northern areas. However, Canada has been much more successful in providing doctors to rural communities than has Australia. As of 1997, the Canadians had one doctor for every 797 people in rural areas whereas in Australia there is only one doctor for every 2,761 people. So Canada has almost four times as many doctors per head of population in rural areas as Australia. Why is it difficult these days to recruit doctors to rural communities in Australia, what has the Howard government done to redress the decline of rural doctors and can the Canadian experience be of any use to Australia?

Rural practice is unattractive to contemporary medical graduates for reasons which can be grouped under four headings. Firstly, working conditions: rural doctors very often are on call 24 hours a day, seven days a week. They suffer professional isolation, lack locum support and local back-up, and the level of technology available in small rural hospitals is usually not what they are used to. Secondly, there are social factors, largely to do with their partner's lack of employment, lack of educational opportunities for their children, distance from extended families, and the tendency of doctors to marry city people who find it hard to adjust to life in small country towns. Thirdly, these days young doctors lack the skills that doctors had 40 years ago: they cannot do anaesthetics, obstetrics or surgery. Finally there is the question of income. The population in rural and remote areas is small and, as with other professions, doctors find that practising in small towns is just not financially viable.

Given that these are the problems, what solutions can be considered? Firstly, it has been found that medical students from country areas are 40 per cent more likely than their city counterparts to be happy to work in the country after graduation. Medical schools are now being encouraged to reserve places for country students and in the recent budget the Howard government provided $4 million over four years to provide scholarships to meet the accommodation and other support costs of country students studying medicine.

Secondly, programs are now in place to specifically train doctors for rural practice so they have the procedural skills required. In WA, the Western Australian Centre for Remote and Rural Medicine, which is largely federally funded, has been very successful in providing general support, locum services and postgraduate education to rural doctors in WA. The federal government is funding the establishment of eight university departments of rural medicine, which will do much to identify the training needs of rural doctors.

Thirdly, addressing the issue of income, the federal government has set up the Practice Incentive Program, which rewards rural doctors and other GPs for providing quality care. In this year's budget the federal government has allocated $43 million to a rural retention grants scheme under which doctors who continue to practise in small rural towns for more than two years will receive cash grants to supplement their incomes.

Ideas promoted by the National Farmers Federation, such as geographic registration under which doctors are only allowed to practise in limited postcode areas in the country, just do not work. Coercing doctors into country practice when they do not want to be there is a recipe for an unhappy outcome all round. An example is the experience in South Africa when, to overcome the shortage of doctors in the country, army doctors were sent to country towns. These doctors resented being sent to the bush. They played a lot of golf and went fishing but were just not interested in remaining in country practice and as soon as they could they returned to the cities.

What has been achieved in dealing with this problem since the Howard government took office? The number of doctors in rural Australia has gone up by 7.2 per cent in the last two years and in remote areas it has gone up by 21.5 per cent. But in spite of this success the fact remains that Canada has four times as many doctors per head of population working in rural areas as we do. What is it that the Canadians do that we do not in Australia? One solution which has been very successful in some Canadian provinces is to put salaried doctors into health centres in small rural towns. In this model, community health centres in these small towns provide a wide spectrum of medical and paramedical services such as physiotherapy, occupational therapy, podiatry, social work and so on. Instead of having just one doctor, the centres have two or three salaried doctors, who thus have a reasonable working roster with adequate time off for recreation and study and who give each other professional support.

The concept of having salaried medical officers in rural areas overcomes many of the problems associated with the present model of traditional private practice in small towns. We do have a similar system to this in some parts of Australia such as in the north of WA where, in the Kimberley small towns like Halls Creek, Fitzroy Crossing and Wyndham as well as larger towns like Derby and Broome, the medical services are provided by salaried doctors working from the local hospitals, which have been turned into community health centres of a kind.

As part of the coalition's 1998 election commitment, the new Regional Health Service Centre Program is an initiative to further improve the provision of health and community care services in rural communities. Regional health service centres will be established in 30 communities which will involve the Commonwealth for the first time in providing funding for primary care medicine at these centres.

What about getting doctors to work in these centres? I believe that in the future, with the restrictions the federal government has placed on the availability of provider code numbers for private practice, it is going to become increasingly difficult to get private practitioners to work in small rural towns. This is because the doctors who obtain provider code numbers, and so can set up in private practice, will inevitably go to the larger towns and cities where they can make more money. So for those doctors who do not have a provider code number the option of working as a salaried medical officer in a regional health service centre will become increasingly attractive.

The question arises as to how such medical officers will be paid. In the Northern Territory, a trial of cashing out Medicare benefits is being conducted. Under this trial all the medical benefits which would have been paid for health services in an area are used to provide medical services, including buildings, equipment and the salaries of health professionals including doctors and paramedical staff. It is an interesting precedent, and I for one will be interested in the outcome of the trial, but there are problems in implementing the scheme.

In the Kimberley region of Western Australia, the state government funds medical services and it is possible that a combination of cashing out medical benefits and a mix of government funding and shire support could be the answer to providing medical services based on this model. The Canadian experience has been that salaried medical officers have been the answer to the provision of medical services in small rural areas and, as such, the Canadian solution could well be the answer to our problems.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Racing, Trotting and Greyhound Coursing Clubs
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 427)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 2 March 1999:

question.para: (1) Will all racing, trotting and greyhound coursing clubs be required to pay the Government's proposed Goods and Services Tax (GST) on all their activities.
(2) If some clubs or some activities are to be exempt from the GST what will be the basis for those exemptions.

(3) Will those clubs that are required to pay the proposed GST also be required to account for all supplies of goods and services used or consumed as part of their activities in staging horse or dog races.
(4) Will each club then be required to file a GST return in respect of each taxation return period.
(5) Will each club also be required to pay GST to the Australian Tax Office within the prescribed taxation return time.
(6) Will all nomination and entry fees paid to horse and greyhound owners to racing clubs attract the proposed GST.

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator Kemp
talker.role: Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) Racing, trotting and greyhound coursing clubs that are registered for GST purposes will be required to charge GST on their activities and will be able to claim input tax credits for the GST paid on purchases of business inputs. Businesses carrying on an enterprise with a turnover of $50 000 or more will be required to register for GST purposes, while those with a turnover less than $50 000 will have the option to register.

(2) GST free treatment exists for certain activities such as health and education services. Chapter 3 of the A New Tax System (Goods and Services Tax) Bill 1998 outlines the activities that qualify for GST-free treatment.

(3) Registered clubs will need to keep records of the value of gross sales of goods and fees charged for services (such as entry fees, ground admission fees, etc.) and gross purchases and tax on purchases. If the gross GST payable in any period exceeds total input tax credits, then the difference will be paid to the Australian Taxation Office. If total input tax credits exceed gross GST in any period, a refund can be claimed.
(4) Clubs registered for GST purposes have a formal requirement to lodge GST returns. In practice, a GST return will be part of the Single Business Activity Statement.

(5) Clubs registered for GST purposes will be required to remit any GST, net of input tax credits, to the Australian Taxation Office within the relevant period. Where the value of input tax credits exceeds the gross GST liability, a refund will be able to be claimed.
(6) Fees paid by horse and greyhound owners to racing clubs registered for GST purposes will be subject to GST. For registered owners, the GST paid can be claimed as an input tax credit.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Thoroughbred and Standard Bred Stallion and Greyhound Service Fees
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 428)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 2 March 1999:

question.para: (1) Will all thoroughbred and standard bred stallion and greyhound service fees attract the Government's proposed Goods and Services Tax (GST) on all their activities.
(2) If some services are to be exempt from the GST: (a) what will they be; and (b) what is the basis upon which an exemption from the GST will be granted.
(3) Where a race horse or greyhound is leased rather than purchased will the lease payments attract the proposed GST.
(4) Will the leases of race horses or greyhounds to non-residents attract the proposed GST.

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator Kemp
talker.role: Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) Entities that are registered for GST purposes will be required to charge GST on their activities and will be able to claim input tax credits for the GST paid on purchases of business inputs. Businesses carrying on an enterprise with a turnover of $50 000 or more will be required to register for GST purposes, while those with a turnover less than $50 000 will have the option to register.

(2) GST free treatment exists for certain activities such as health and education services. Chapter 3 of the A New Tax System (Goods and Services Tax) Bill 1998 outlines the activities that qualify for GST-free treatment.

(3) Yes, where the lessor of the race horse or greyhound is a business registered for GST purposes. However, where the lessee is a registered business, the lessee will be able to claim input tax credits for the GST paid on the lease.
(4) If the horse or greyhound is situated in Australia, the lease to a non-resident would attract GST. If the horse or greyhound is exported, the lease would be GST free.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Horse Racing Jockey's and Trotting Driver's Fees
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 430)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 2 March 1999:

question.para: (1) Will horse racing jockey's and trotting driver's fees attract the Government's proposed Goods and Services Tax (GST).
(2) If there are any exemptions: (a) what are they; and (b) what is the basis for these exemptions.
(3) Will horse and greyhound trainer's fees attract the Government's proposed GST.
(4) If there are any exemptions: (a) what are they; and (b) what is the basis for these exemptions.
(5) Will all veterinary fees associated with the racing of horses or greyhounds attract the Government's proposed GST.
(6) If there are any exemptions: (a) what are they; and (b) what is the basis for these exemptions.

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator Kemp
talker.role: Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) Entities that are registered for GST purposes will be required to charge GST on their activities and will be able to claim input tax credits for the GST paid on purchases of business inputs. Businesses carrying on an enterprise with a turnover of $50 000 or more will be required to register for GST purposes, while those with a turnover less than $50 000 will have the option to register. Where a jockey or trotting driver is an employee, their salary will not be subject to GST but, subject to the registration threshold, the fee charged by their employer for their services will. However, horse or greyhound owners registered for GST purposes will be able to claim input tax credits to offset the GST paid on business purchases, including horse racing jockey's and trotting driver's fees where these services are purchased from a registered business.

(2) GST free treatment exists for certain activities such as health and education services. Chapter 3 of the A New Tax System (Goods and Services Tax) Bill 1998 outlines the activities that qualify for GST-free treatment.

(3) Entities that are registered for GST purposes will be required to charge GST on their activities and will be able to claim input tax credits for the GST paid on purchases of business inputs. Businesses carrying on an enterprise with a turnover of $50 000 or more will be required to register for GST purposes, while those with a turnover less than $50 000 will have the option to register. However, horse or greyhound owners registered for GST purposes will be able to claim input tax credits to offset the GST paid on business purchases, including horse and greyhound trainer's fees where these services are purchased from a registered business.

(5) Where the veterinary surgeon is registered for GST purposes, GST will be charged. However, horse or greyhound owners registered for GST purposes will be able to claim input tax credits for the GST paid on business purchases.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Sale of Thoroughbred, Standard Bred Horses and Greyhounds
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 432)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 2 March 1999:

question.para: (1) Will the sale of all thoroughbred horses, standard bred horses and greyhounds attract the Government's proposed Goods and Services Tax (GST); if not: (a) what sales will be exempt from the GST; and (b) what will be the basis of those exemptions.
(2) If horses or greyhounds are sold by auction will the commission and other charges imposed by the auctioneer also attract GST.

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator Kemp
talker.role: Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: —Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) Where the seller is registered for GST purposes, GST will be charged. However, buyers of horses and greyhounds registered for GST purposes will be able to claim input tax credits for GST paid on business purchases.

(2) Where the auctioneer is registered for GST purposes, GST will be charged. However, businesses registered for GST purposes will be able to claim input tax credits for GST paid on business purchases.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Totalizator Agency Board Profits or Turnover
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 433)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 2 March 1998:

question.para: (1) Will the Government's proposed Goods and Services Tax (GST) be imposed on the Totalizator Agency Board (TAB) profits or turnover.

(2) Have all states agreed to drop state-based taxes applying to TAB profits or turnover if a GST is imposed on them; if so; (a) which states have agreed; and (b) when were those agreements reached; if not, will a GST be imposed on TAB profits in addition to the state-based taxes they pay currently.
(3) Has Treasury undertaken any assessment of the amount of revenue a GST would collect from TABs.

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator Kemp
talker.role: Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) In regard to its gambling operations, GST will apply to the TAB's gambling margin, that is, total wagers less total monetary prizes. The TAB will be able to claim input tax credits for GST paid on business purchases.
(2) In respect of State taxes on gambling, the tax reform document "Tax Reform—not a new tax—a new tax system" (ANTS) noted that:

"As the States already tax gambling highly there may need to be corresponding reductions in State gambling taxes. This will be possible because, under the proposed arrangements, the States will receive the proceeds of the GST, including the GST on gambling."

Accordingly, the States and Territories signed the Intergovernmental Agreement at the Premiers Conference on 9 April 1999 agreeing to adjust their gambling taxation arrangements to take account of the impact of the GST on gambling operators.
(3) Treasury has not specifically estimated GST revenue from the TAB.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Racing Prize Money
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 434)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 2 March 1999:

question.para: (1) Is the activity of racing a thoroughbred horse, a standard bred horse or a greyhound a taxable activity under the Government's proposed Goods and Services Tax (GST).
(2) Does that mean any prize money won by the racing of a horse or dog will be subjected to a GST.
(3) If the activity of racing is a business can the owner or the lessee claim all GST paid in inputs into that activity.
(4) If the activity of racing is a hobby or recreational pursuit can the owner or the lessee claim GST inputs paid into that activity.
(5) What tests will be used to differentiate between business and recreational participants in racing for the purposes of the application of a GST.

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator Kemp
talker.role: Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) The activity of racing a thoroughbred horse, a standard bred horse or a greyhound is subject to the GST. For registered businesses undertaking racing activities, prizes won will be treated as consideration for a supply of racing services while input tax credits will be allowed for the GST paid on the costs incurred in the course of the business.

(2) GST will be included in prizes paid out by racing clubs to registered owners. However, because the racing clubs can claim the GST paid out in prizes as an input tax credit, there is no need for prize money to fall. A GST registered owner of the horse or dog will be required to remit 1/11th of the prize if it was won in the carrying on of an enterprise.

(3) Horse or dog owners registered for GST purposes will be able to claim input tax credits for the GST paid on purchases of business inputs. Businesses carrying on an enterprise with a turnover of $50 000 or more will be required to register for GST purposes, while those with a turnover less than $50 000 will have the option to register.
(4) See answer to question (5).

(5) An entity who genuinely owns horses for the purpose of racing and carries on that activity in a business like manner (ie with a reasonable expectation of profitability and therefore collecting GST on outputs) should expect to satisfy the tests for being treated as carrying on an enterprise as set out in s 9-20 of A New Tax System (Goods and Services Tax) Bill 1998.

answer.para: (4) (a) and (b)

Each of the above Consultancies was performed by a number of consultants undertaking a varying number of days work and at different rates depending upon the level of experience of the individual. subdebateinfo.title: Work for the Dole Projects: Assessment and Approval
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 606)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment Services, upon notice, on 23 March 1999:

question.para: (1) (a) Whose responsibility is it to assess and approve work for the dole projects to ensure that participants will be adequately trained, supervised and supported; (b) what criteria are applied to make the assessment; and (c) when and how are approved projects audited to ensure that training, supervision and support are in fact adequate.

(2) (a) Whose responsibility is it to ensure that participants in the work for the dole program have suitable qualifications, experience and character to be placed in specific projects; (b) what resources are required to be allocated to this task; and (c) what measures are in place to ensure that agencies do not waste the time of unemployed people or project organisers by referring people who are inappropriate for the work.

(3) What funding does the Commonwealth provide to organisations to cover the costs of taking on work for the dole participants, including interview and selection costs, and resources for supervision, training and support.

(4) Are work for the dole participants provided with worker's compensation insurance; if not, what protection do they have if they sustain a chronic injury in the course of participating in such a scheme.

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator Alston
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Employment Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) (a) Work for the Dole project applications are assessed by the Department of Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business assessment teams. Recommendations on projects for approval are made by a ministerially appointed National Selection Advisory Committee. All projects are approved by the Department's Group Manager for Labour Market Programs and Services.
(b) The Department of Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business applies the following selection criteria when assessing applications to ensure only projects of high quality are chosen:
* the proposed project properly reflects the needs of the local community;
* the ability of sponsors to monitor and support the progress of participants during the placement;
* the ability to provide support for participants on completion of the placement; and
* the ability to provide the services on a cost-effective basis.
A minimum assessment score must be met for each criterion in order for a project to be considered for funding.

(c) The Department of Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business monitors all Work for the Dole projects in order to ensure satisfactory performance by the sponsor in terms of contractual compliance and quality of service. The most important sources of information which Departmental officers use on an ongoing basis to monitor projects are:
* sponsor performance reports during the project and on conclusion;
* at least one project site visit by Departmental staff to ensure that sponsors are adhering to the objectives of the program and complying with the specified Code of Conduct; and
* feedback on the project from participants and the public made either directly to the Department or via Centrelink.

(2) (a) Centrelink determines the eligibility of job seekers to participate in the Work for the Dole program. Satisfying the general eligibility requirements does not guarantee a place on a Work for the Dole project as Centrelink takes into consideration other factors such as the participant's overall health and suitability. Sponsors are encouraged to participate actively in the recruitment process and to liaise closely with Centrelink staff to attract eligible job seekers to their project.

Where participants are involved in schools and childcare centre projects, sponsors must use appropriate selection procedures so as to ensure that only suitable participants are chosen. These procedures include:
* the Principal (or equivalent) participating in interviews to select participants;
* the Principal (or equivalent) agreeing to the selection of a particular participant;

* the project sponsor must make reasonable enquiries, including obtaining two referee reports from appropriate persons who have known the prospective participants for a minimum of five years and confirming the authenticity of the referee reports; and
* police checks to be carried out to establish that no participant has any record of convictions for crimes against children within Australia.

(b) Under a Service Arrangement with the Department of Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business, Centrelink allocates appropriate resources to assess the suitability of eligible job seekers to projects. Sponsors may include costs associated with recruitment of participants, as well as the fee for police checks if required, in their budget.

(c) Eligible persons undertake an interview with Centrelink staff and/or with the project sponsor to ascertain whether they are suitable for a project. They will not be referred to a project if they are not considered suitable. If the sponsor has a legitimate concern about the suitability of a person who has been recommended to their project, they are invited to discuss their concerns with their Centrelink contact.

(3) Funding for successful sponsors varies and depends on the length of the project, the number of placements and type of project being proposed. In developing a budget, sponsors can factor in appropriate interview and selection costs, including the fee for police checks required in special projects, as well as reasonable costs for supervision, training and support. Other costs that sponsors can include in their budget submission are:
* project staff wages and on costs;
* administration;
* advertising/marketing of the project in the local community;
* purchase of materials to be used in the project;
* equipment leasing costs, including transport vehicles;
* on-site services such as toilets or catering facilities;
* appropriate insurance;
* costs for training of participants;
* safety equipment for participants; and
* the audit of the project at its completion.

(4) Work for the Dole participants are not provided with workers' compensation insurance as they are not defined as being employees whilst participating on a project. The Commonwealth purchases personal accident and general liability insurance for participants to cover injuries incurred through participation in Work for the Dole projects. The personal accident insurance covers all participants against accidental bodily injury or death arising from their involvement in a Work for the Dole project activity. These benefits are paid irrespective of fault, without having to prove negligence. The policy does not cover loss of earnings as, in the event of a disability, the participant will be entitled to some form of income support.

Work for the Dole project sponsors are also required to purchase their own public liability insurance that covers Work for the Dole participants. In the event of a disability to a participant caused by the sponsor's negligence, the participant can make a common law claim. Participants are advised that if they have concerns about their treatment or any occupational health and safety matters during the placement they can contact Centrelink or the relevant Departmental officer.

subdebateinfo.title: Wentworth Rural Land Protection Board: Drought Exceptional Circumstances
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 644)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, upon notice, on 30 March 1999:

question.para: (1) What work did the then Bureau of Resource Sciences (BRS) undertake on the application from the New South Wales Government for a drought exceptional circumstances (DEC) declaration for the Wentworth Rural Land Protection Board (RLPB) in September 1997.
(2) What conclusions did BRS reach about that application.

(3) Did BRS undertake any further work on subsequent applications from the New South Wales Government for DEC or exceptional circumstances declarations for the Wentworth RLPB; if so: (a) what additional work did BRS undertake (b) when was that work undertaken, and (c) what was the outcome from that work.

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator Alston
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) BRS provides assessments of biophysical conditions to the Rural Adjustment Scheme Advisory Council (RASAC) when it evaluates exceptional circumstances (EC), including drought (DEC).
BRS provided a report to RASAC on 11 November 1997 assessing the biophysical criteria for DEC in the Wentworth Rural Lands Protection Board (RLPB) until the end of October 1997.

(2) This report confirmed the NSW Agriculture analysis of rainfall, concluding that the Wentworth RLPB did not meet the meteorological (trigger) criterion for DEC. Based on available data including analysis of rainfall within the nominated growing seasons and satellite information provided by NSW Agriculture, BRS assessed that the region did not meet the agronomic criterion for DEC.
(3) Yes

(a) In relation to the NSW Government EC application for the Wentworth RLPB, BRS provided RASAC with an assessment, evaluating historical climate variability compared to conditions ending July 1998, effectiveness of rainfall, production conditions and outlook and implications for productive sustainabilty.
(b) BRS commenced work on 24 July 1998, and a final report was provided on 27 August 1998.

(c) The report concluded that rainfall deficiencies in March 1994-April 1995 and October 1997-July 1998 were the dominant factors which led to a progressive decline in the pasture resource since 1994, and that conditions in July 1998 were comparable to the 1982/83 drought. BRS advised that management factors, including high stock numbers maintained during the 1994/95 period and the reported dependence on annual species, had intensified the impact of dry conditions on the pasture resource and increased the vulnerability of agricultural systems in the district to rainfall variability.

subdebateinfo.title: Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport: Runway Rotation System
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 662)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 13 April 1999:

question.para: (1) Has Airservices Australia (ASA) developed a runway rotation system to operate at Sydney Airport.
(2) When was the project approved by the Board of ASA.

(4) Did the board consider a detail project schedule for the implementation of the runway rotation system, including; (a) time-line; (b) estimated completion dates; (c) resource allocation for each task; and (d) budgets relating to each task and subtasks.
(5) Was the Minister, or his office, provided with a project schedule for the runway rotation system; if so, when was this information provided; if not, why not.

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator Ian Macdonald
talker.role: Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Transport and Regional Services has provided

answer.para: the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

(1) to (8) The selection of Runway Modes of Operation (RMO) at Sydney Airport is carried out according to a system of preferences set out in the Long Term Operating Plan for Sydney Airport (LTOP) and subject to the operational criteria in the Australian Aeronautical Information Publication (AIP).
